tickets.description:
Why is it that idno isn't obligatory in msIdentifier?
Right now it is possible to describe \(or refer to\) a
manuscript only with settlement and repository but no
further identification.
Instead of the current definition

msIdentifier.content =
\(
\(
country?,
region?,
settlement,
institution?,
repository,
collection?,
idno?
\)
| msName
\),
\( altIdentifier | msName \)\*

I would suggest to declare either this

msIdentifier.content =
\(
\(
country?,
region?,
settlement,
institution?,
repository,
collection?,
idno
\)
| msName
\),
\( altIdentifier | msName \)\*

or this

msIdentifier.content =
\(
\(
country?,
region?,
settlement,
institution?,
repository,
collection?,
\( idno | msName \)
\)
| msName
\),
\( altIdentifier | msName \)\*

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

Basically because we need to be able to deal with cases 
where there is no <idno>, for example if there is only an 
<msName> or a series of <altIdentifier>s. The current 
content model is the only one that will allow us to cater 
for all the possibilites we could think of, without allowing 
for all kinds of nuttiness. -- MJD
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #67 idno in msIdentifier obligatory?

posts.text:
- **priority**: 5 --> 3
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard

posts.subject: #67 idno in msIdentifier obligatory?

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146

I am closing this request. Of course, an ODD can easily 
make idno mandatory for applications where this is 
appropriate, but given the existence of cases where it is 
not, I think MJD's response is persuasive.

tickets.description:
A few of the attributes available on the <hand> element seem not to have 
the right datatype for their function as described in the text of P5. 

The @writing attribute has the datatype data.enumerated. P5 indicates 
that it  is intended to contain a description of the characteristics of the 
hand, but these characteristics are not likely to be describable in mutually 
exclusive terms without some difficulty. In particular it would be difficult 
to describe multiple characteristics \(e.g. "thick and shaky" or "blotted and 
oversized"\). Is there a datatype available that would permit multiple 
tokens?

The @ink attribute has the datatype data.code. This seems like an odd 
choice; would a better choice be data.enumerated?

posts.text:
- **priority**: 5 --> 4
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> sbauman
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #69 improve datatype of <hand> attributes

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> PH
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #69 improve datatype of <hand> attributes

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

I agree with both these observations: I think @writing should be data.words, and @ink data.enumerated.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #69 improve datatype of <hand> attributes

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=686243
Originator: NO

This request comprises two separate issues,
which I will address separately.


The writing= attribute of <hand> \(and also
<handShift>\) is currently declared as datatype
data.enumerated, which limits it to a single
value. This is insufficient. However, data.words
would not permit the capability to restrict the
value\(s\) to those in a list of documented
possibilities. Currently only data.code and
data.enumerated provide this highly desirable
capability.

However, there is no theorhetical reason not to
have a datatype in which multiple choices from a
list of documented possibilities. I.e., to have
either a data.codes or a data.enumerateds.

Furthermore, for Relax NG \(and I believe W3C
Schema\) users, there is no reason the schema
could not permit multiple values while
simultaneously enforcing that those values come
from the previously declared list. \(DTD users
will not have this advantage.\)

So, after some quick discussions, we have
implemented a quick although not ideal mechanism
for handling this: a new datatype that is the
equivalent of "data.enumerateds". However, since
"enumerateds" is not only not a word, it isn't
clear, the names have been changed to
"data.selection" and "data.selections". \(These
names have not been approved by Council yet, and
are subject to change.\)

The current mechanism consists of a new
repeatable= attribute on <valList>. This does
work, and a new version of P5 that makes use of
it has been checked into a development branch on
Sourceforge \(called "P5-selections"\). However,
this is not the best way to achieve this effect.
A better solution would be to specify the
repeatability of the tokens in an attribute
value on the <datatype> itself.

I am very hopeful that, perhaps even within the
next few days, such a mechanism can be hammered
out and implemented in P5. However, if it cannot
be, at least the original poster's desired
result -- being able to specify more than one
value for writing= of <hand> \(and of
<handShift>\) will be met.

Therefore, even though the feature is not merged
into the trunk development branch pending what
mechanism to use, I am closing this part of the
feature request.


The second part of this feature request is a
suggestion that perhaps the ink= attribute of
<hand> \(and of <handShift>, and arguably the
medium= attribute of <handNote>\) should be of
datatype data.selection, rather than data.code.
\(The difference is primarily where the
documented list of possible values resides -- in
the former case it is inthe schema, in the
latter it is in an XML document, typically but
not necessarily the header of the document that
contains the data.code attribute.\)

After speaking to the original poster, it
becomes clear that her preference would be, in
order:

\* data.code, with a defined place in the TEI
Header for the codes to be declared, e.g. an
<inkList>
\* data.selection
\* data.name
\* data.word

and I completely agree. However, it seems very
unlikely that we have the time at the moment to
create, flesh out, agree upon, and implement a
proposal for a specific place in the TEI Header
to list possible values of this attribute in
time for the scheduled 1.0 release.

Therefore I have chosen my \(and the original
poster's\) second choice, and changed ink=
attribute of <hand> and <handShift>, and the
medium= attribute of <handNote> to
data.enumerated \(in the trunk\) and to
data.selection \(in the new branch\).
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #69 improve datatype of <hand> attributes

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #69 improve datatype of <hand> attributes

tickets.description:
This module consists of two elements and one attribute
which can be used to record detail about an
authoring/editing application which has operated on a
TEI file. The main purposes of the module are: Its main
purposes are: 

1\) to allow an application to discover that it has
previously opened/edited a file, and what version of
itself was used to do that; 

2\) to show \(through a date element\) which application
last edited the file to allow for diagnosis of any
problems that might have been caused by that application; 

3\) to allow users to discover information about an
application used to edit the file; 

4\) to allow the application to "declare an interest" in
elements of the file which it has edited, so that other
applications or human editors may be more wary of
making changes to those sections of the file.

posts.text: appDesc.odd: contains elementSpecs for appInfo and appDetail elements, and adType attribute.

posts.subject: #70 Elements for describing authoring/editing tools

posts.text:

The exemplum shows the lastSave date like this:

<appDetail name="lastSave"><date
value="2006-06-01"/></appDetail>

It should probably be a full date/time value, like this:

<appDetail name="lastSave"><date
value="2006-06-01T11:15:05"/></appDetail>

Either would be technically valid, but when we're comparing
file timestamps \(for example, to discover which application
last edited a file\), the time component will be essential.

Cognate with the prosopographical work on listPerson,
person and personGrp, I would like to suggest that
there be a listPlace, place and placeGrp.

Unlike person, place should be self-nestable and
contain at least model.placeNamePart if not model.addrPart


In addition there should be something in content model
of  place which allows the recording of abstracted
information about a place.  \(For example, Latitude,
Longitude, Map co-ordinates, GIS information, ref's to
URLS, etc.\)


-James

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146

This is a plausible item for further work as part of the ND
revision. 

Can you suggest a use for <placeGrp>?

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard

posts.subject: #72 listPlace, place, placeGrp

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=612078

I'm assuming that <placeGrp> would work in a parallel manner
to <personGrp>.  So in this case describe a group of places
treated as a single place for analytic purposes.

My entirely hypothetical use case might be something like
recording GIS information in archaeological reports.  If a
particular individual archaeological object has certain
contours or separate points one can identify, but overall
one wants to treat it as the same location, then placeGrp
would be a possibility for that.  

Is there any semantic difference between location and place
by the way?  should this be
location/listLocation/locationGrp ... is that less tied to
assumptions about geography?  \(I actually prefer place, I'm
just playing devil's advocate.\)

-JAmes

FWIW I would vote for altering the definition of <supplied> to allow it to be used for this purpose \(as we do in EpiDoc, see http://www.stoa.org/projects/epidoc/stable/guidelines/abbreviationsunderstood.html \).

<expan><abbr>Aug</abbr><supplied reason="abbreviation">ustus</supplied></expan>

tickets.description:
<person> has attributes "role", "sex" and "age". There
are elements <role> and <sex>. Please can there also be
an element <age> having similar attributes to <sex>.

The work on personography
<url:http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/PERS/persw02.xml?style=printable>
is excellent and the argument presented there for an
element <sex> that is datable was successful

However the personography work seems not to address the
challenge that any text reports only a facet of an
individual's biography. That is, the text presents a
persona. A person may be reported male in one text and
female in another and therefore have two sex personas.
It is good that TEI can now record this successfully.
This has nothing to do with the mutability of sex as a
characteristic.

The position with age is similar to that with sex in
that there may be more than one text recording the age
of an individual. They may not agree and may not be
consistent with respect to the implied date of birth.
However each presents a valid persona.

Examples of how <age> may be used include in orbtuaries
routinely which mention the age of the deceased at
death. That is the report of a person's age is
localised with respect to some date, say 5 March 2006;

<age value="90" dateValue="2006-03-05">four score years
and ten</age>

or a record of marriage dated 5 April 1806 which may
state that the bride is of full age;

<age value="21" notAfter="1806-04-05">full</age>.

It would simplify the task of encoding transcriptions
of memorial inscriptions, census ennumeration books,
marriage registers and the like no end to provide <age>
as an element in TEI.

posts.text:
- **priority**: 5 --> 7
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #75 <age>

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146

The children of <person> are mostly elements for which one 
can make a fairly strong case that they are more likely 
than not to appear in most kinds of historical record. The 
examples you suggest make this more plausible, certainly, 
and I will therefore suggest that we consider adding a 
<age> element as you propose when the ND module is reviewed 
next. \(This review is likely to take place quite soon, for 
other reasons\) If the WG disagrees with you, it will 
probably suggest instead <persTrait type="age">\! 

FWIW I think the presence of age as an \*attribute\* is 
actually harder to defend, since it is \(by definition\) 
something that changes over time.

tickets.description:
If I read the definition of data.temporal correctly
\(chapter 3.5 Guidelines P 5.041\) so in addition to the
types of W3C Schema there are values allowed if their
pattern is like

\(-?\[0-9\]\{4\}-\(0\[1-9\]|1\[0-2\]\)-\(0\[1-9\]|\[12\]\[0-9\]|3\[01\]\)T\)?\(\[01\]\[0-9\]|2\[0-3\]\)\(:\[0-5\]\[0-9\]\)?\(Z|\[+\\-\]\(\(0\[0-9\]|1\[0-3\]\):\[0-5\]\[0-9\]|14:00\)\)?

Question 1: Is it a typo or what is the reason to make
"T" mandatory for dates \(or do I read the pattern wrongly\)?

Question 2: Is the year 0 allowed to be able to tag
dates as proposed by ISO 8601?

Question 3: What is the reason not to allow month or
day 00 \(eg if it was not known\)?

Question 4: Why are only years allowed in the range
-9999 to 9999?

If I want to use dates from the Stone Age to the far
future in an "intuitive" way a pattern like 

-?\(\[0\]\{4\}|\[0-9\]\{0-3\}\[1-9\]\[0-9\]\*\)-\(0\[0-9\]|1\[0-2\]\)-\(0\[0-9\]|\[12\]\[0-9\]|3\[01\]\)

for the date part seems to be more appropriate:
For unknown year, month or day 0000 or 00;
no mandatory time zone.

The patterns for day may be refined to exclude February
30 and 31.

Is there anything wrong with my pattern?

K. Märker

\-- 
K. Märker
Digitale Bibliothek
Bayerische Staatsbibliothek
Email: karl.maerker@bsb-muenchen.de

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=686243

Yes, you've read the definition of data.temporal
correctly. This datatype permits a string that matches
any of the W3C Schema date & time datatypes, OR a
string matching that long-winded pattern.

That pattern exists solely to permit times to be
recorded without minutes or seconds. The W3C datatypes
require that minutes and seconds be specified, but the
TEI datatype does not. The pattern is the portion of
the datatype that permits times \(or dateTimes\) without
minutes or seconds.


> Question 1: Is it a typo or what is the reason to
> make "T" mandatory for dates \(or do I read the
> pattern wrongly\)?

Not a typo. The pattern does not match dates \(which are
matched by xsd:date instead\), but rather only matches
times with reduced precision or dateTimes with reduced
precision.


> Question 2: Is the year 0 allowed to be able to tag
> dates as proposed by ISO 8601?

No. Per \_XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition\_
appendix D.3.2: 'The year "0000" is an illegal year value.'
However, it is expected this will be corrected someday. See
http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xmlschema-2-20041028/\#year-zero.
That note states that 8601:2000 permits 0000, but it was
published too late to be included. Note that 8601:2004 also
permits 0000.

However, you have correctly noticed that the TEI
pattern for representation of a dateTime with reduced
precision \*does\* permit "0000". This, it seems to me,
is an error \(on my part\).

If there is demand for use of "0000", TEI would be
happy to consider including it in the TEI datatype.


> Question 3: What is the reason not to allow month or
> day 00 \(eg if it was not known\)?

Good question. The answer is pretty simple, if a bit of
a cop-out: because neither ISO nor W3C permits it.
\(Although the W3C specification does seem to leave
wiggle room.\) However it is a bit odd to know the year
and the hour, but not the month or day. But in such a
peculiar circumstance, you are right, the regularized
form TEI recommends cannot be used to record that
information. \(Separate use of the <year> and <hour>
elements might be put to the task.\)


> Question 4: Why are only years allowed in the range
> -9999 to 9999?

Values outside the range -9999 to 9999 \*are\* allowed
for in the representation of a date, year, year &
month, or date & time. But you are right, years outside
that range are not permitted in the representation of a
date & time with reduced precision. Perhaps just an
oversight on my part, or perhaps it was felt that no
one would want to represent a point in time that far
away down to the hour, but not to the second. Again, if
there is demand for this, TEI would be happy to
consider including it in the TEI datatype.


> If I want to use dates from the Stone Age to the far
> future ...

You would be relying on the xsd:date datatype, and
whatever the TEI does with its pattern for reduced
precision would not affect you. If you wanted to
represent dates & times with reduced precision from the
stone age or the far future, you would be very
frustrated that the TEI limits you to 4 digits for the
year, and would submit a bug report. :-\)


> ... a pattern like
>
-?\(\[0\]\{4\}|\[0-9\]\{0-3\}\[1-9\]\[0-9\]\*\)-\(0\[0-9\]|1\[0-2\]\)-\(0\[0-9\]|\[12\]\[0-9\]|3\[01\]\)
> for the date part seems to be more appropriate: For
> unknown year, month or day 0000 or 00; no mandatory
> time zone. ... Is there anything wrong with my
> pattern?

First, note that the timezone is not mandatory in the
TEI pattern for representation of times with reduced
precision or dateTimes with reduced precision.

As for the semantics of the pattern, I think use of
"0000" for an unknown year is a very bad idea, in light
of the W3C intention to follow ISO 8601 and permit it
for representation of the year 1 BCE.

The use of "00" for an unknown month or day is not
necessarily a bad idea on its own, but the fact that is
not permitted in ISO 8601 nor W3C makes me think TEI
should not do that either.

As for the pattern itself, I'm not sure why limit the 0
version of the year to four digits.


I am inclined to say that either 

a\) the TEI pattern for reduced precisions should match
the W3C datatypes and not permit the year "0" \(until
such time as the W3C datatypes permit "0", and then
they should\); OR

b\) the TEI data.temporal datatype should side with ISO
\(breaking with W3C until they catch up per their
note\) and permit the year "0", whether with reduced
precision or not.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #76 data.temporal

tickets.summary: extend and generalise names and dates
tickets.description:
The existing Names and Dates module could act as the
basis for a generic tagset for encoding assertions
about real-world events.  A review of the CIDOC
Conceptual Reference Model class hierarchy \(see
http://cidoc.ics.forth.gr/definition\_cidoc.html\)
suggests something like this would be a good
starting-point:

Period
\- Event
\- - Activity
Object
Actor
\- Group
\- Person  
Time-span
Place
Dimension

\(Indentation indicates superclass-subclass
relationships between element types.\)  I have omitted
the "appellation" part of the framework, on the grounds
that the names of these entities will be recorded as
subelements, as at present.

The CIDOC CRM properties could be represented by
generic "role" and/or "type" attributes, whose values
could be constrained for particular applications.

I think that most requirements could be met by using
period/event/activity as a group element, holding the
parties involved in that episode as subelements.  This
is very much how persEvent is currently used.

It must be possible to encode this information
out-of-line as well as inline, since the source text
may not allow a single element to neatly group all the
elements of an assertion.

posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 3
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #77 extend and generalise names and dates

tickets.description:
On behalf of textual editors who need to link textual
components -- e.g., letters or even strokes as well as
marginalia, erasures, damage, superscripts,
illuminations, etc. -- to the occurrence of these
components in a digital facsimile of the text \(e.g., a
monograph page, a manuscript folio, a cuneiform tablet,
a papyrus scroll\), I propose a new global attribute
named @coord. The @coord would facilitate integration of
text and image. Editors creating image-based editions
\(see, for example, the Projects at
http://www.eppt.org/eppt-trial/EPPT-TrialProjects.htm\)
would be able to use the @coord to document the x/y
coordinates for the text-to-image correspondence.

The WWP requests that the <catRef> element be added to
the att.typed class. \(Scheme is not sufficient -- one
can have several classifications of a text that use the
same scheme, but are differentiated in some other
manner, e.g. "main" and "subordinate".\)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

I am not sure I agree with this. The difference between main/subordinate is a difference in the thing being pointed at -- i.e. the category in the case of a catRef -- not in the thing doing the pointing. <category>s can of course be nested and organized and typed and everything else. But a catRef is just a pointer. If you wanted to have values for @type on a pointer they would have to be things like "long distance", "fuzzy", "mistaken" or some such wouldn't they?

posts.text: - **status**: pending --> closed
posts.author: sf-robot
posts.subject: #81 give <catRef> a type= attribute

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=686243
Originator: YES

Ack\! Sorry for the delay, and thanks to the
SF-robot for reminding me. :-\)

I may be misinterpreting the semantics of
<catRef> and <category>, in which case
enlightenment appreciated.

"The <catRef> element categorizes an individual
text … The <category> element … holds
information about a particular classification or
category within a given taxonomy" \[3.4.3\] We'd
like to be able to classify the categorization
of a text, not a particular classification.

E.g., Suppose we have the following classification scheme.

<taxonomy>
<\!-- ... -->
<category>
<catDesc>needlework</catDesc>
<category xml:id="knit"><catDesc>knitting</catDesc></category>
<category><catDesc>crochet</catDesc></category>
<category><catDesc>weaving</catDesc></category>
<category><catDesc>sewing</catDesc></category>
</category>
<\!-- ... -->
<category>
<catDesc>ships</catDesc>
<category xml:id="sail"><catDesc>sailing</catDesc></category>
<category><catDesc>steam-powered</catDesc></category>
<category><catDesc>nuclear-powered</catDesc></category>
</category>
<\!-- ... -->
</taxonomy>

Now suppose we have a text we're encoding that
we'd like to classify. It is primarily about
knitting, but \(by way of pointing out there are
some things which really can't be knit, of which
a mainsail is one\) the author takes a lovely
chapter-long tangent discussing sailing ships.
This tangent, in fact, is so interesting it has
been quoted several times in the sailing
literature. So we really can't ignore it, but we
don't want to give the impression this book is
\*about\* sailing, because it is primarily about
knitting.

The method that jumps to mind to encode this is

<textClass>
<catRef type="main" target="\#knit"/>
<catRef type="subordinate" target="\#sail"/>
</textClass>

Certainly it is not the case that, in general,
sailing is subordinate to knitting. In fact you
may well have a different text that is primarily
about sailing, but \(by way of discussing ways
sailors should pass the time on long voyages\)
has a lovely chapter about knitting\!

So I think this "how relevant is this
classification to this text" feature is squarely
a feature of <catRef>, not of <category>.

But we could also ask "why does <catRef> has a
target= of its own, rather than inheriting it
through att.pointing, in which case it would
have a type= attribute\!"

However, the type= attribute provided by the
class att.pointing "should indicate the intended
function of the pointer, or the rhetorical
relationship between its source and target."
\[tagdoc\] Thus while it does not strictly
describe the type of pointer \(absolute URL,
relative IRI, IDREF, etc\), I can see that its
semantics don't precisely line up with
describing the type of categorization, either.

So at the moment I don't have a definitive idea
on how to do so, but it seems clear to me that
it is a good idea to be able to categorize a
<catRef>'s \*classification\* function \(as opposed
to its \*pointer\*\) according to any convenient
typology.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #81 give <catRef> a type= attribute

posts.text: - **status**: closed --> open
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #81 give <catRef> a type= attribute

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

<catRef> is intended to provide a set of pointers to categorisations broadly applicable to the whole of a text. It is a blunt instrument used quite a lot by corpus linguists \(but few others\) who just want to indicate broadly what a text is like. In particular it's not really meant to provide a more nuanced set of topic descriptors as you seem to be suggesting -- for that we provide all sorts of other clever mechnisms \(@decls, @ana, interp...\). If your book is about both knitting and sailing, then point to both topics\! A more realistic example would be to say that the topic of the book was \(say\) knitting and the target audience was age groups 10 to 16. You \*might\* want to say that the target age group included over 50s too, but it was primarily for 10-16 year olds, but I don't think anyone ever would.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #81 give <catRef> a type= attribute

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #81 give <catRef> a type= attribute

tickets.summary: Changing conten models in drama tags
tickets.description:
I propose that <sp> should allow a many <speaker> as
well as <stage> elements and that they should be
allowed in any sequence and with mildestone elements
between them.

Alternatively I suggest that <speaker> should be able
to contain <stage> and vice versa.

Espen S. Ore
espen@espenore.tk

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #82 Changing conten models in drama tags

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

As currently defined, the <speaker> element is maybe a bit misleadingly named. It doesn't mean "name of one speaker", but "the heading given in the text to indicate who is speaking". So it would make no sense to have many <speaker> tags -- unless you are suggesting that multiple such headings occur, which I don't think you are. 

However, I agree that it would be useful to permit <stage> within <speaker>. Which in fact you already can.

tickets.description:
If we want to allow to keep information about a
manuscript together in a file \(like the custodialHist\)
it would be an idea to add to <history> a new element
<usage>. Here would be grouped information about users
\(and publications deriving from the usage?\) and loans
\(e.g. for exhibitions\).

Content then could be formed by elements of
model.nameLike.agent and model.dateLike.

posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 4
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #83 usage history

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146

The distinction between <history> and <custodialHist> is
that the former relates to things which happend to the ms
before it came into the collection, and the latter to things
that happened afterwards. I think the things you're talking
about are all types of custodial event: certainly there are
examples of people using this element to record such things
as loans for exhibitions. 

The <provenance> element is used within <history> to record
anything that happened to the ms between its creation and
its acquisition, so could be used for things like loans as
well. 

I am therefore closing this request: feel free to open it if
you would like to suggest a different element name for
<provenance> or if I have completely misunderstood\!

tickets.description:
TEI should consider changing the content model of
<category> from
\( catDesc, category\* \)
to
\(
\( model.glossLike | model.catDescPart \)+,
category\*
\)

Or perhaps, equivalently, adding model.glossLike to the
class model.catDescPart and using just
\( model.catDescPart+, category\* \)

Unlike the previous request \(1550229\), I have no use
case in mind for this. It may turn out to be a bad
idea. But it permits a more nuanced and more detailed
category description. Especially now that a single
<taxonomy> element can be stored in 1 location for an
entire project, and every file can point to it, it may
make a lot of sense to put more detail into a taxonomy.

posts.text: - **priority**: 3 --> 4
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #84 replace <catDesc> with model.glossLike

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146

The suggestion also makes the way categories are defined
more consistent with the way other things are -- in fact, if
we adopt it, I can see people asking why  we need a
<catDesc> element at all... so this suggestion would allow
me to put \*less\* detail into a taxonomy as well as more.

Seems like a good idea to me. In fact, I'd suggest we make
the content model \(\(catDesc | model.glossLike\)+, category\*\) 
and note that catDesc is only provided here for backwards
compatibility.

tickets.description:
As discussed on TEI-L in July 2006, subjects "lemma
\(and app\)" and "lemma and app".

\(cf. also FR 1019594 Manuscript encoding\)

The apparatus element <app> is extremely well designed
for the encoding of critical apparatus as they are used
in ecclectic manuscript editions, i.e. the recording of
textual variants or editorial restorations, which is as
it should be. However, there is a significant body of
textual editions which have a slightly wider use of
apparatus to describe important features of a text that
exists in a single exemplar and therefore does not
necessarily have textual variants. For reasons already
discussed on-list, I would make the following two
recommendations \(to be considered independently\):

\(1\) allow the element <note> to appear immediately
inside <app>, as well as within <lem> and <rdg> as
currently;

\(2\) make <rdg> within <app> optional rather than
required, so that an <app> could contain, for example,
just a <lem>, or even \(more radically\) just a <note>.

Am willing to return to this discussion privately or on
TEI-L if necessary.

posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 7
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
- **status**: open --> pending

Logged In: YES 
user\_id=222320
Originator: NO

I dont quite see why you need app to record features of just one textual witness.  That does not seem what this element is intended for.
posts.author: cwittern
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407
Originator: YES

This seems to be a difference in manuscript editing practice \(with multiple sources\) and single source editing \(such as epigraphy or papyrology\). In the latter disciplines it is not uncommon to have an apparatus below the text--as in ms editions--but this apparatus will tend to contain different restorations and interpretations of a single text rather than MS variants. Sometimes an entry such as "l. 3, \_editiones\_, Bernard; \_editionum\_, P & H" might appear alongside one such as "l. 4, \_ab.\[...\_, the final letter might be o or e", or even a comment such as "The final letters of every line are very badly worn."

Of course the use of <app> within a text to record variant readings is not affected by this argument, but the use of <app> to list variants and notes in an "apparatus" at the end of the text, marked-up externally, I believe is. I would like to be able to use the same element to tag each item in this list.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=222320
Originator: NO

I acknowledge your point, but am still not convinced that <app> is the right thing for this use case, being tight as it is to multiple variant encoding.  We already do have a whole set of tags for transcription of primary sources.  What seems to be amiss is a way to gather them together in one place as "apparatus".  But could this not be done with a <div type="apparatus"> somewhere, rather than using a specialized element?
posts.author: cwittern
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407
Originator: YES

Right. We do use a div for this. But how to tag each item in the list? Some are <app>, clearly. Others are very similar kinds of comment or remark, just happening not to involve variants. All I am suggesting is that we make the content model a tiny bit less strict, to make <rdg> optional rather than required.  99% of such items include at least one reading or lemma; it seems cumbersome to have to use a different element \(what, <note>?\) for those few that do not. Messes with my xsl:for-each, for starters. ;-\)
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=222320
Originator: NO

Well, having an <app> without a <rdg> should not really break anything.  We already do allow the opposite, a <app> without <lem>, so you have managed to convinced me that this is not a bad thing after all.  Great\!

Christian
posts.author: cwittern
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

\(a\) As a consequence of a change made earlier today, <note> is now available immediately within <app>.
\(b\) I have changed the content model so that an <app> can now contain:

\- i.   nothing at all

or any or all of the following

\- ii.  just globals \(includes note\)
\- iii. a single lem, followed by globals and a wit
\- iv.  multiple  rdgs or rdgGrps, each followed by globals and a wit

The one thing this  won't permit is a solitary wit, without some indication of what it's supposed to be a wit of \(a lem or rdg\), which seems right to me.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

posts.subject: #85 Make <app> model less strict

tickets.description:
As the element <extent> might be used within a
bibliographical entry or a manuscript description, the
meaning and usage is much broader as the explanatory
text suggests. Thus, the explanation of the element is
to narrow and should be changed.

Right now it reads:
"describes the approximate size of the electronic text
as stored on some carrier medium, specified in any
convenient units."

It might be changed to something like:
"describes approximate sizes of any kind like the size
of the electronic text as stored on some carrier
medium, or the amount of pages in a book or the size of
pages of a book, etc. All of these are specified in any
convenient units."

tickets.description:
I propose to add new attributes @rotate to the class
att.placement.

Reason: One may want to describe how text has been
placed on the page in the source and as the orientation
of a portion of text might not alway be the same as of
the rest of the text or the binding, an attribute
@rotate would allow to encode exactely this.

Values: Reasonable values might be 0-360 for the
degrees of the rotation if we predefine the direction,
preferably clockwise. Otherwise we would need another
attribute @direction to allow rotation to both directions.

Additionally to that it might be useful to supply an
attribute for information whether text has been
mirror-inverted.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=686243

Overall seems like a good idea at first blush. But I am
immediately concerned with "where des it end"? There are
\*lots\* of things one can say about the rendition of text on
a page. So far TEI has remained mostly agnostic on the
issue, dumping most such details into the all-in-one-bag
attribute rend=. I am not suggesting for a moment that TEI
never tackle the issue of rendition. But I am suggesting
that a piecemeal approach may not be the right way to do
this. Personally, I'd prefer to see the place= attribute
dropped \(expecting users to wrap such information into
rend=\) for now, and tackle rendition \(including placement,
rotation, curve of baseline, etc., as well as the usual
typeface, fontsize, indentation, etc.\) with a full workgroup
sometime in the future.

If we do adopt rotate= \(which might be better called angle=
or rotation=\), I am in favor of including the direction so
that we do not need a second attribute to indicate CW or
CCW. However, do we want to insist people use degrees?
Wouldn't some people prefer grads, radians, or revs?
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #88 add attribute(s) to att.placement

tickets.summary: Header record of possibly external metadata

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

I am puzzled by this proposal. Everything in the TEI Header is metadata, so why do I need a special component to record some particular kinds of metadata? What is the defining characteristic of the metadata you'd want to put in it? Is it just that it's a pointer elsewhere? Why not just put that into a <note> in the existing <notesStmt>? 

Alternatively, if it's the need to have a defined home for the schema or ODD associated with a given file, I would have thought the place for it would be in the <encodingDesc>, possibly with a new element named something like <schemaDefinition> but that's not what you seem to be proposing.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #89 Header record of possibly external metadata

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #89 Header record of possibly external metadata

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=612078
Originator: YES

I was trying to conflate two ideas.  Lou has convinced me that metadata in other namespaces should be scattered around the header into its most appropriate location.  However, yes, I still want a place to indicate the relationship of a document instance with its schema and/or ODD.  So having <schemaDefinition> inside <encodingDesc> would be a possible place to put this.

<schemaDefinition> should then maybe allow children of <ptr> or maybe <ref>?  \(Or list? and <p> or note?\)
It might be nice if <schemaDefinition> also allowed <schemaSpec> as a child for those sick people who want to embed a copy of the ODD in the document instance.

tickets.description:
Using <publicationSmt> inside <biblFull> for a born digital CV, there seems to be no simple way to indicate either the 'status' of the publication or what degree of refereeing it had.

By status I mean things like 'Forthcoming', 'Submitted', 'Accepted', and 'In Press'. And for refereeing I mean either simply whether it was peer reviewed or not, or in some cases who was responsible for that peer review.

Neither <availability> nor <authority> were designed for these uses.

Use Case: I'm thinking of using this CV to generate versions of the information which require this information to be present.

-James

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

Neither of these seem to me to be the kind of things you'd expect to find in a bibliographic description, so it's not surprising there is no tag for them in a biblFull. The best I can suggest would be to add a <note> of the requisite type, inside the <notesStmt>.

Reason: The meaning of the element <unclear> is it to supply some information about text that is for some reason unreadable. The extent of the unreadable passage should be noted somewhere. The element <gap> has the same purpose and is allowed to have the attribute @extent.

tickets.summary: Need Header element to reference or embed schema/odd
tickets.description:
We need a header element to reference or embed a schema or odd that the document is meant to validate against.

This should be able to cope with different namespaces... i.e. I should be able to reference the relaxNG schema for elements starting with rng: the tei: schema I'm using, the svg: schema I'm using, etc.  

I should be able just to point to an ODD, an RNG, etc.  or embed my ODD etc.

-james

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> rahtz
posts.author: louburnard

Logged In: YES 
user\_id=95949

posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #92 Need Header element to reference or embed schema/odd

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #92 Need Header element to reference or embed schema/odd

posts.text:
Re-opening for re-consideration given Laurent's discussion on TEI-L of 2010-11-19.  

The idea is that there should be some place in the header in which one can embed schemaSpec\*  allow embedding of ODD instances inside document instances and/or pointing to external encoding declaration vocabularies.  Simultaneously we want a method to point to an external ODD \(or similar schema or meta-schema source\), but this has now been answered with @source on schemaSpec.

So my proposal is that schemaSpec as a child of encodingDesc.  i.e. make it a member of model.encodingDescPart and that the guidelines make some mention of this possibility.  The recommendation for when you just want to point to an external ODD then would be to use schemaSpec as an empty element with a @source attribute pointing to the source.

While there is not necessarily one canonical ODD for any particular document instance, and schemas may vary at different points in any workflow, it seems that this feature may be desirable in some form.

But this is marked as 'RED'  because it needs to be discussed more.

-James

tickets.description:
As I recently discovered, somewhere along the road to P5, we lost the ability to indicate the writing direction of a document.  This used to be part of the WSD in P4 and we still can have the \(default\) direction on individual characters via their Unicode properties in P5, but there seems to be no way to indicate this with markup on other levels. One could conceive this as a job for the @rend but than we are out in the open wilderness that reigns there.

Now what to do? I am inclined to propose an attribute that could either be part of model.global by default or be selected independently \(or maybe part of the gaiji module?, but in reality, this is quite a separate question\).

HTML 4.01, btw does define this as follows:

dir    \(ltr|rtl\)  \#IMPLIED  -- default directionality --

\(see http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/dirlang.html\)

On the other hand, we should also account for indicating how the sequence of lines proceed on the page, which is separate from the text direction indicated by @dir, but could use the same set of possible attribute values, 
e.g. 
ltr = left to right
rtl = right to left
ttb = top to bottom
btt = bottom to top \(dont know of a sample, but just for completeness\)

Maybe one could combine these values, so that no additional attribute is needed beside @dir,
e.g.
<p dir="ltr.ttb">This paragraph is written from left to right and the lines proceed from top to bottom, as is normal for modern western writing</p>.

One last problem is the Boustrophedon. From the Unicode glossary \(http://unicode.org/glossary/\):
<q>
Boustrophedon.A pattern of writing seen in some ancient manuscripts and inscriptions, where alternate lines of text are laid out in opposite directions, and where right-to-left lines generally use glyphs mirrored from their left-to-right forms. Literally, “as the ox turns,” referring to the plowing of a field.
</q>
How do we handle this?

\---
Needless to say that I would rather see this in P5, since it would be a bit embarassing to come out of the woods with so little of the homework done.

Christian

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

It may be a wilderness, but @rend really is the right place to specify this isnt it?

The directionality that was available in the old WSD related to the directionality of the \*writing system\* not the specific way it was written in the text, I think. We have that information now as a Unicode property, so if we want to record exceptions at the individual occurrence level, there is nowhere else but @rend to do it.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #93 writing direction of text

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #93 writing direction of text

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407
Originator: NO

In EpiDoc we cope with boustrophedon \(and texts that are more complex than that, perhaps with lines mostly in one direction but occasionally in another\) by using the @rend attribute on the <lb/> at the beginning of that line. We use <lb/> at the start of the text, as well as the beginning of lines 2 following.

<lb rend="right-to-left"/>...

\("Left-to-right" is the default, but can be expressed if necessary in a mixed text.\)
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #93 writing direction of text

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=222320
Originator: YES

Well, the boustrophedon was more an afterthought, but it is really a different type of problem.  What I have in mind is a text that is completely written in vertical lines, right to left -- as is usual practice in premodern Chinese and Japanese.  I do not want to record this fact on every <p> in the whole text, I'd rather say it, for example on <text> and have it propagate down to the last little note two lines before the end, in the same way, for example, the @xml:lang works.  Do we allow this kind to proliferation with @rend as well?
Christian
posts.author: cwittern
posts.subject: #93 writing direction of text

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

"inheritance" might be a better word than proliferation\! However, I suggest the thing you want here may be  the <rendition> element in the header which "is used to hold a description of the default rendition to be associated with the specified element"

If you have suggestions for text which could go into the Guidelines to discuss further how to deal with this problem, please make them\! But I don't think we need a new element, so I am closing this ticket for now.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #93 writing direction of text

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

tickets.description:
Currently, the <gap> and <space> elements use @extent to indicate the size of the gap.  My colleagues and I at the Epidoc project have for some time been using an extended DTD with a @unit attribute added to these elements to allow the separation of the numeric measurement from the unit of measurement, which may be lines, characters, or standard units of measurement like centimeters. 

We notice that something very similar has been done with <measure> in P5 with the att.measurement class \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/html/ref-att.measurement.html\) where @quantity and @unit have been split into two and we think @extents should be treated the same way in P5.  The split will allow the values of @unit to be easily constrained and will also make it easier to query and manipulate @extents programmatically.

Some examples:

\[ · · · \] \(the Leiden notation for three missing characters\) would be encoded as:
<gap reason="lost" extent="3" unit="character" />

\[ - 4.2cm - \] would be encoded
<gap reason="lost" extent="4.2" unit="cm" />

Imperator \(vac. 3\) Caesar would be encoded:
Imperator <space dim="horizontal" extent="3" unit="character" /> Caesar

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

Sounds eminently sensible to me. I've updated the relevant TRAC ticket \(\#328\) with a pointer to this suggestion.

tickets.description:
I'd like to propose a slight refinement to the way imprecise numerical values \(e.g. dates, measurements, extents of gap or space, etc.\) are expressed. In general terms, the distinction I would like to see enabled \(even recommended\) would be that between the expressions:

\(a\) "Date: c. A.D. 250"
\(b\) "Date: A.D. 250?"

The former is an expression of imprecision; the editor is fairly confident that the object or event she is dating happened pretty close to the middle of the third century, but isn't going to commit to that precise year. The latter is an expression of uncertainty; the editor may have evidence that the event occured in precisely that year, but is not entirely happy with her interpretation of the evidence. They are not the same thing. \(In the sciences there is often this same distinction between precision and accuracy, for example.\)

Now I see that in <date> there is already a precision attribute for this purpose, but I would like to see this extended to elements such as <gap> and <space> \(where it would refer to the precision of @extent\), and <measure> \(where it would modify @value\). This has been the practice of the EpiDoc Guidelines for a while now, since we believe the certainty mechanism is inadequate \(and in any case inaccurate\) for this purpose.

For example:

"H. c. 0.50" could be represented:
<measure type="length" dim="height" precision="low" value="0.50">

"\[ . . c. 12 . . \]" would be:
<gap reason="lost" extent="12" precision="low"/>

This would involve simply the addition of an attribute to the model of these elements and so would be fully backward-compatible with earlier versions of P5.

\(I'm also going to float this for discussion on the list, because I think it's an important concept worth getting people's opinions on.\)

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> jcummings
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #95 Precision attribute

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

See also comments on TEI-L from Tim Finney on 26/2/08
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #95 Precision attribute

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

Council agrees that a new
@precision attribute with possible values high, medium,low should be
added to att.dimensions class. However, there is no such attribute
on date at present: it should probably be added to att.editLike. 
In more
complicated cases, a new <gi>precision</gi> element will be needed: this
should be put forward as a new proposal.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES

I have now added the attribute @certainty to att.dimensions and att.editLike with a datatype of data.certainty \(giving values of . This is the same datatype as is used for @cert on att.editLike, but of course there is a difference between high certainty and high precision. Probably some discussion of this should be added to the discussion of the <date> etc elements.

tickets.description:
The semantics of @facs are vague and potentially ambiguous, risking interoperability problems. Software may interpret the link between text and image as either transcription \(as did all the demo software developed during the development phase of the facsimile module\), or, more broadly, as any kind of correspondence \(as the Image Markup Tool now does\).

I suggest that the @facs attribute should be reserved for linking facsimile images to transcriptions, and that the @corresp or @ana attributes should be the recommended mechanism for linking images to annotations or commentary.

A thread on TEI-L discussed this issue. My final email on the subject was also cross-posted to the TEI Council list:

http://lists.village.virginia.edu/pipermail/tei-council/2007/009301.html

The proposed change is only to the documentation and does not change the formal model, which already permits @corresp and @ana in such a way.

tickets.description:
TEI Guidelines recommend using <gap reason="deleted"/> in case of unreadable deletions \(cf. a note in the description of <del> http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-del.html\),
but <gap> is not allowed within <subst>, which the tag designed for grouping deletions and additions \(its content is model.pPart.transcriptional\).

I wonder whether adding model.global.edit to model.pPart.transcriptional would not be the best solution. It looks logical and might solve other potential problems.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

Council  recommends that deletion within a substitution should always and
only be marked using the <gi>del</gi> element, for consistency of
treatment. Where the material deleted is illegible, a <gi>gap</gi>
may be used within the <gi>del</gi>. The suggestion of using <gi>gap
reason=deleted</gi> in the Guidelines has been removed.

tickets.description:
From the "should have remembered this months ago" department …

Back in August of 1999, I added a type= attribute to the <tag> element for the Women Writers Project. The declaration would the following in RELAX NG.

attribute type \{ "start" | "empty" | "end" \}

In truth, if we really wanted an element for describing markup constructs in an XML instance, we would have something more like

element markup \{
attribute type \{ "start" | "empty" | "end" |
"pi" | "comment" | "ms" \},

or go whole-hog and use constructs similar to <xsl:element>, etc.

But those ideas are overkill. But having a type= on <tag> allows the element to be more consistent. As it is now, one transcribes some of the characters that delimit the tag in the source as content, and some are subsumed by the <tag> element, as in the example in the tagdoc:

Mark the start of each italicised phrase with a
<tag>hi rend="it"</tag> tag, and its end with a
<tag>/hi</tag> tag.

Using type= would allow all the tag delimiting characters to be represented by markup:

Mark the start of each italicised phrase with a
<tag type="start>hi rend="it"</tag> tag, and its
end with a <tag type="end">hi</tag> tag.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=35379
Originator: NO

The Guidelines say "<tag> contains text of a complete start- or end-tag, possibly including attribute specifications, but excluding the opening and closing markup delimiter characters". The practice currently required to have a "/" delimiter display in the end tag, namely including it literally as <tag>/hi</tag>, contradicts the recommendation of the Guidelines. Adding tag/@type would be a solution.
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #99 typing <tag>

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

This has been implemented: since the values of the <att>type</att>
attribute are to be constrained, the attribute must be locally defined

tickets.summary: Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting
tickets.description:
The following relates to what started me reading the guidelines--trying to be able to follow the discussions so as to try to solve the few problems we have in getting our formerly P4 documents to validate. The following are the only essential barriers we have, and I wonder whether this might also be an issue for others too possibly. I have some more ideas such as those shared during the course of discussing the documentation, but which I plan on holding of on submitting \(if you even would like ideas which are not immediately needed\) since it is only this request which is essential for us.\)

1\) In closer \(via divBottom?\):  figure, bibl, meeting
2\) In byline \(via titlepagePart, pLike.front, divTop, divBottom, or divWrapper?\): figure, bibl, meeting
3\) In docTitle \(via titlepagePart, pLike.front?\): figure
4\) In bibl \(via inter?\): figure
5\) In opener \(via divTop?\): meeting
6\) Allow <figure> after a closer \(as in a div3\)  \(via divBottom or global?\)

We'd also like to see <meeting> in running prose \(where I think <event> would also be useful\). The requests for <meeting>, however, are not as critical for us, since we can use <name> if necessary, but those pertaining to the placement of <figure> and <bibl> are.

Would adding <meeting> and/or model.biblLike \(bibl\) to model.phrase, and/or changing model.inter to work inside of divBottom/divTop/global/pLike.front work? Sorry, I still have little understanding of the class system, but just wanted to offer something.

Please let me know if there any other details I should supply.

Brett

posts.text: - **labels**:  --> TEI: New or Changed Element
posts.author: brettz9
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1102990
Originator: YES

We'd also like the ability to have a <bibl> within opener too.
posts.author: brettz9
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1102990
Originator: YES

Yet one more related request is to allow <quote> to contain elements like <opener>, <closer>, etc. I see that <floatingText> is allowed in <quote> but

A\) It seems like floatingText is more for floating narratives, sidebars perhaps, etc.
B\) While in our case it is a genuine letter, and not fiction, the Guidelines state: "Where a character in one narrative quotes from some other text or narrative, fully or in part, the <quote> element discussed in 3.3.3 Quotation should be used instead."
posts.author: brettz9
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1315071
Originator: NO

At the council meeting I've been assigned this issue. Mailed to Brett the following:

...
At our last meeting, the TEI council went through the open feature requests, among which is the one you opened, mentioned above. We felt that some of things you ask for seem reasonable, but 
\- we really need to see some examples for the issues that you bring up;
\- it's a number of quite different issues that you raise, so we may need to create a number of requests, and discuss them separately;
\- you suggest this may be a P4-P5 conversion issue \('the few problems we
have in getting our formerly P4 documents to validate...'\). Is it true you could validly do the things you ask for in P4?

Could you mail me a number of examples, perhaps including page images, that show the things that you need? And is this indeed also a conversion issue? 
...
posts.author: pboot
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1315071
Originator: NO

After some mailing back and forth we identified at least these three issues:

1\. It seems P5 made a div that contains first a div, then a figure invalid. Raised that matter on the council mailing list \(http://lists.village.virginia.edu/pipermail/tei-council/2008/009823.html\)

2\. A bibl can 'accidentally' be interrupted by a picture, e.g. in the case of an inserted page with images. Raised the matter of how to deal with that situation on TEI-L \(http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0807&L=TEI-L&T=0&F=&S=&P=401\)

3\. Some of the other issues result from complex postscripts \(that actually include another letter\). Referring to issue 1928212 \(Make postscript more div-like\) it seems best to encode the postscript in these cases as a separate div. The new correspondence SIG will definitely need to have another look at letter-like poststcripts.
posts.author: pboot
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

The first proposal \(to add <figure> to model.divBot\) seems quite reasonable and I have opened a new ticket for it.

The second, as the ensuing discussion on TEI-L demonstrates, seems to miss the point. The figure inside the bibl is not \*part\* of the bibl, any more than the <pb/> is, so it would actually be wrong to permit within its content model. My prefered solution would be to put the <figure> after the <bibl>, and indicate its position inside the <bibl> by means of a <ptr>. 

The third point, I think, is closed: divLike postscripts should be tagged as <div type="postscript">
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

On further examination, I have now realised that adding <figure> to model.divBottom is not an option. The members of divBottom must be disjoint with the members of model.common \(which -- via model.inter -- includes figure\). Otherwise the content model of <div> becomes ambiguous. As Sebastian notes, you can put <figure> inside <epigraph>, since that has a richer content model, but all the other divBottom elements only permit phrase level elements as content: so you could put a <graphic> inside one of them -- which might make better sense.  In general <graphic>, as a member of model.phrase, is available in most of the places you mention above.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #101 Expanding placement options for figure, bibl, meeting

I added information about the two proposals concerning figure placement identified earlier in this request \(2008-07-01\) to that bug. If figure is indeed made global \(to be discussed in Coucil meeting in Lyon, april 2009\), that obviates the need for further discussion of these proposals here. I would then propose that we open new requests for the other issues discussed here \(about meeting and quote\), if still required.

tickets.summary: provide more detailed lists for datatypes, attributes, &c
tickets.description:
Along the lines of my suggestion above to list attributes and elements using a given data type, I think it could also be very useful to:
1\) list all elements where a given attribute is used \(listing all attributes individually\). I.e., an alphabetical list of attributes \(not merely the attribute classes\) with their corresponding elements.
2\) \(Optionally?\) expand "Used by" with names of and links to the members of those classes \(added parenthetically as is done with the listing of attributes within attribute classes\). Also, would it be accurate to rename this field "contained by"? I think this would be much more clear to a newcomer to TEI.

The above two \(and \#5 above that\) should I would think be automatable \(such as via XSL or an XQuery\), though I don't know how processor-intensive \(if you're not caching\) or how large the results in some cases might be.

tickets.description:
Content model for <interp> and possibly some other formerly empty elements should permit only model.glossLike or text rather than model.limitedContent \(which is not limited enough\)

See discussion on TEI-L 25/3/08

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

See http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0803&L=TEI-L&T=0&F=&S=&P=7527 for details
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #105 <interp> content model is too permissive

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

In P4, <interp> was an empty element. In P5, it was given a content 
model of model.limitedPhrase, which I now think was a mistake: it needed 
to become non-empty so that the textual description of what the interp 
means could be supplied as content rather than \(as previously\) by a 
@desc attribute, but it should only permit child elements such as <desc> 
or <gloss> \(model.glossLike in fact\). Otherwise we permit all sorts of 
ambiguity such as you sketch out here -- in my view, the correct way to 
nest <interp>s hierarchically is within <interpGrp>s, as you say, and 
<interp> should not be permitted within <interp>

You can still include <ptr>s within your <desc> of course.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #105 <interp> content model is too permissive

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

Council agrees, noting however that the description of
the <gi>desc</gi> element needs generalizing. A <gi>desc</gi> child of
<gi>interpGrp</gi> is also needed. Specifications for <gi>interp</gi>
<gi>interpGrp</gi>  
model.glossLike and <gi>desc</gi> have been modified accordingly.

tickets.description:
see discussion on tei-l around 25-2-08

because @lemma is data.word it does not permit lemmata which contain spaces. 
we could
a\) document this restriction
b\) change the datatype of @lemma to string or token
c\) remove the @lemma attribute in favour of a <lem> child
or some other more complex construct

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=686243
Originator: NO

Or \(d\), add maxOccurs="unbounded" to the <datatype> element in the ODD.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #108 resolve  @lemma datatype problem

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

Council noted that the use of the @lemma attribute to hold textual
data was inconsistent, but also recognised that this was a very common
usage. The simplest solution appeared to be to change the
datatype so as to permit spaces. Council also proposed adding a new
@lemmaRef attribute to point to a definition of the lemma held
elsewhere. This would provide a pair analogous to the @key @ref attributes
on name etc. The child element solution 
would also require  definition of some other child element to hold the
non-lemmatised form. Changing @maxOccurs would introduce
ambiguity. Some more prose is needed to introduce the new attribute
within \#AISP.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407

\(1\) @extent and @unit on gap are to be suppressed, and instead gap will be made a member of att.dimensions, which gives it @quantity and @unit.

\(2\) att.dimensions is to be extended by the addition of attributes: @from and @to \(to indicate ranges of quantities\); @atLeast and @atMost \(for uncertain/imprecise quantities\).

\(Anything more complicated than this we should recommend using the new <precision> element rather than trying to express it with the att.dimensions attributes.\)
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text:

posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

The trouble with this is that we also decided to add @precision to both att.dimensions and att.editLike.
Adding <gap> \(which is a member of att.editLike\) to att.dimensions would thus give it the same attribute twice.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407
Originator: NO

I'm not sure why att.editLike is getting the @precision attribute then. I should argue that 'gap' should take quantity and precision in the same way as 'space' \(and date, measure, num, etc.\). So the essential question is, how do we add the @precision and related attributes to 'gap', 'space', 'date', 'measure', 'num', and various dimensions elements? \(What others need @precision?\) Surely any element in att.editLike that needs @precision also needs the other att.dimensions attributes--since precision only has any meaning if applied unambiguously to a quantity--so @precision shouldn't be in att.editLike in the first place. \(If for some reason you want to apply precision to 'supplied', for example, you should use the new 'precision' element to do so.\)
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=612078
Originator: NO

I agree with Gabby that @precision only has meaning when there is a quantity  -- otherwise we're talking about @cert which is different. I've upped the priority on this because although it may be 'Amber' in that it still needs some sorting out, I think it is something we should definitely try to do for the next release.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 7
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #110 Review usage and precision of @extent

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=597407
Originator: NO

After discussions of ticket \#1933198 \(on new <precision> element\), I think that:

\(1\) we need to define the four new attributes proposed below \(@min, @max, @atLeast, @atMost\) in a new attribute class, perhaps att.ranging or similar. \(<precision> will then be a member of att.ranging but not att.dimensions.\)

\(2\) @precision should be defined within att.dimensions \_\_but \*\*not\*\* att.editLike or att.ranging\_\_.
posts.author: gabrielbodard

posts.text: At rev 4787, I added @min, @max, @atLeast, @atMost, @extent to att.dimensions; removed local definitions for @extent on <gap> and in att.damaged; removed @precision from att.editLike; made att.damaged and att.editLike subclasses of the new att.dimensions. Quite  a bit of wording in the text still to be revised, but this seems to address most of what's required here.

tickets.description:
"'data', 'rend', 'std' and 'nonstd' \(as well as unknown'\) are listed as possible values of <quotation form=>. It seems to me that the first two ought to be possible values of one attribute, while the second two were 
possible values of their own attribute.

Presumably one could, for example, standardize use of quotation marks by including them everywhere as data, or everywhere as @rend.  As it is now, indicating this is not possible. And does @marks="some" imply @form="nonstd"? Can @marks="all" be used with @form="rend" to indicate  that all quotation marks were retained but via @rend?

It gets even more confusing when one attempts to consider what this all means when multiple <quotation> elements are present with their own xml:id and @decls referring to them. Would, for example, one be able to indicate @marks="all" for one <quotation> and @marks="some" for another \(if in those respective contexts it was always or only sometimes applied\)."

\(from BZ on TEI-L  9/2/08\)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

Council's opinion was that the  @form attribute was not useful, and
should be deprecated,  and
removed at a later release. The element spec has been updated
accordingly; in particular, the closed value list has been removed.

tickets.description:
As per Peter Boot's suggestion, on TEI-L, 

http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0803&L=TEI-L&P=R5816&D=0&H=0&O=T&T=0 

that there may be a case where <facsimile> and <surface> may wish to override defaults in the header, these should be added to to the att.declaring class.  The use-case example for this was in having an <availability> element which applied to the text as a whole, but another one which applied to the collection of images... or indeed specific images.  In the later case there is an argument that <graphic/> should be also added to att.declaring if you want to have a collection of <graphic/> elements inside your <facsimile> which have different availabilities associated with them.  \(i.e. the lowres/hires issue, or the normal images are freely available, but not the reconstructed or uv ones\).

Transferred from TEI-L to here so that it can be considered at some point by council.  While it is not simply a corrigible error, it has few effects on backwards compatibility.

-James

tickets.description:
Before the release of P5 we had agreed on the addition of an attribute @period that could point to named time periods.

Quoting from Lou's email \(April 2007\) to the council list \(http://lists.village.virginia.edu/pipermail/tei-council/2007/007409.html\): 

"Named time periods. The treatment of dates and times has just undergone major surgery in order to support various kinds of automatic processing and validation, mappings to both ISO and W3C date formats etc. When the patient is mobile again, I agree that we need to start 
thinking about "named" dates. It should not be too difficult."

So, at the moment, we do have the attribute @period as member of att.datable and its definition quotes:

"@period supplies a pointer to some location defining a named period of time within which the datable item is understood to have occurred."

but we don't have any examples of this use. This slipped given more important priorities just before the launch \(see http://lists.village.virginia.edu/pipermail/tei-council/2007/008873.html\).

tickets.description:
\[posted at the request of Martin Mueller, who is 
struggling with the incompatabilities between
the TCP postscript element and the similar element
adopted later in P5. The language below is mine, not
his. -- pfs.\]

Though it is good to have a postscript tag in P5, the
present definition is difficult to apply to a large
number of actual postscripts. Many, perhaps most,
postscripts have their own openers and/or closers, for
example \(datelines and signatures especially\); many 
have heads \(or at least headings that are very similar
to the things that we call heads in the case of the
argument element\); and a few may even contain internal
divisions of a div-like character.

Less critically, the placement of the P5 postscript
element among the div-bottom tags, instead of 
within closer, often forces a somewhat artificial
closing of one closer and reopening of another 
in order to allow postscript to fall between them.

\[pfs: I would add that forcing typical epistolary
features into TEI tags is not infrequently difficult,
especially enclosures, endorsements, seals,
directions, and notarization statements. Enclosures
can usu. be handled by floatText \(or equivalent
q/text/body/div\) within postscript, though that may
be abusive, but the others are difficult to handle
at all satisfactorily. The TCP tag to which Martin
is comparing P5's postscript is defined as follows,
largely on the basis of 'literary warrant'  -- i.e.,
tables are not allowed simply because none have
been encountered yet\):

<\!ELEMENT postscript 
\(\(head | opener | lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*,
\(\(p | l | lg | q | list | letter | note | stage | sp | bibl\), 
\(lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*\)+,
\(\(closer | tailnote | trailer\), \(lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*\)\*\)  >

\(For 'letter' read floatText \(or floatDiv\!\); for
'q' read 'quote' \(as in P3 TEI lite\)\).

TCP's tag is currently allowed only within closer. 

We haven't really worked out a satisfactory way to tag the other epistolary difficulties.\]

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

This seems to request two different things:
\(a\) the ability to include div-liminal elements within a <postscript>
\(b\) the ability to include <postscript> within <closer>

Is there any good reason not to treat the first case as a <div type="postscript">?

The content model of <closer> is a bit strange: it permits phrase level stuff, text, and three specific elements \(signed, dateline, salute\). Adding <postscript> would be possible if we wanted to make it even stranger, I suppose, though I fear it might introduce ambiguity. 


Please could you supply examples of some typical problem cases?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #114 Make postscript more div-like

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=35379
Originator: NO

In working with documentary editions \(Papers of George Washington, etc.\) we've seen plenty of cases of the sort Paul notes: "Many, perhaps most, postscripts have their own openers and/or closers, for example \(datelines and signatures especially\); many have heads \(or at least headings that are very similarto the things that we call heads in the case of the argument element\); and a few may even contain internal divisions of a div-like character." 

But as Lou suggests, a postscript this complex should probably be treated as a div. It is very common to find a letter composed over the course of two or more days, often divided by the author into sub-letters with separate datelines, and such letters would naturally be tagged using separate <div> or <divN> elements. It seems to me that the purpose of a separate postscript tag is really to handle formulaic postscripts \("P.S. I love you\!"\) rather than complexly structured additions that just happen to follow a signature.
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #114 Make postscript more div-like

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

I am closing this, pending a more thorough investigation of epistolary matters. As David says, structurally complex postscripts should be handled as <div>s.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #114 Make postscript more div-like

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: YES

A bit of googling suggests that ISBD has moved on a little since it was used as the basis for the TEI's definitions. In particular, ISBD\(M\), and hence the most recent consolidated ISBD, both suggest that we ought to have a special slot for <idno> somewhere. \(cf the following quote from IFLA:"The major part of the work consists of specifications for the eight elements: \(1\) title and statement of authorship; \(2\) edition; \(3\) imprint; \(4\) collation; \(5\) series; \(6\) notes; \(7\) International Standard Book Number \(ISBN\), binding, and price; and \(8\) multivolume publications."\). So I think this is probably a bug, and we should probably review the content models for bibliographic elements again.

tickets.summary: add summary to handDesc and history
tickets.description:
The structures of <handDesc> and <history> are parallel to <msContents> in the way that in the descriptions a summary part may exist, followed by more specific, distinct information about parts of the summarized content. Thus it would make sense to add <summary> to the respective contents models which then would look like this:

handDesc
\( model.pLike+ | \( summary?, handNote+ \) \)

history
\( model.pLike+ | \( summary?, origin?, provenance\*, acquisition? \) \)

Whether these two and <msContents> should be generalized to a new model \(e.g. model.summaryLike\) which has the form

\( model.pLike+ | \( summary?, model.distinctItems+ \) \)

and model.destinctItems
\( handNote+ | 
\( origin?, provenance\*, acquisition? \) | 
\( textLang?, \( msItem | msItemStruct \)+ \) 
\)

can be further explored.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1021146
Originator: NO

This was independently requested by MJD as well: I have now implemented it.
