tickets.summary: quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?
tickets.description:
COHQQ says that quotation marks may be retained in the text \(as character data\) rather than removing them when inserting <said>, <q>, <soCalled>, etc.  However, no guidance is given on whether the quotation marks should remain inside or outside the tags:

\(A\) "<tag>text</tag>"

\(B\) <tag>"text"</tag>

It seems we should recommend one over the other to promote interchange.

posts.text: Given that e.g. <q> and </q> tags are often automatically rendered as quotation marks, a recommendation to leave quotation marks \*in the presence of tags\* appears quite interesting. What's COHQQ, please?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: COHQQ is the xml:id on section 3.3.3 of P5.  This section recommends removing quotation marks but says they might be left in as character data.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text:
You probably mean this passage:

"quite independently of their description by the rend attribute"

I'm wondering: wouldn't it be good to remove this recommendation altogether, in view of statements such as "This section discusses the following elements, all of which are often rendered by the use of quotation marks", which implicitly suggest \(it seems to me\) that it's \*either\* quotes or tags?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text:
I was referring to the whole sentence: "Quotation marks themselves may, like other punctuation marks, be felt for some purposes to be worth retaining within a text, quite independently of their description by the rend attribute. This should generally be done using the appropriate Unicode character, or, if this is not possible, a numeric character reference \(see Character References\)."  I take this to mean you could leave quotation marks as character data in addition to inserting soCalled, q, said, etc. at the beginning and end of the quoted phrase.

I understand the sentence "This section discusses the
following elements, all of which are often rendered by the use of quotation
marks" to refer to rendering in the source document, not how the TEI document is encoded or to be rendered.  Clarification there would be good.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: Well, at least I think I managed to confirm your intuition that there is \*something\* to be clarified here, one way or another\! :-\) I'm quite curious as to how this is going to get resolved.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: The text is fairly clear I think. You can remove the quote marks if you insert tags. If you retain the quote marks and \*also\* insert the tags, I agree that the doc doesn't tell you where to put them. I can see arguments for either possibility, Anyone care to make a recommendation?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: Natasha Smith favors putting them inside the tags, and I think that's probably easier to read.  However, I could live with it either way.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text:
What is said, mentioned, quoted, etc., is the given piece of text, not the piece of text surrounded by quotes. Quotes are just ambiguous character markup that gets disambiguated by the more specific TEI tags. If this premise is right, then tags should be inside quotes. It's a bit like <w> and </w> tags not surrounding the "edge" whitespace, but rather just the character strings, the "edge" whitespace staying between <w/> elements.

Possible counterargument: <s/> elements containing dots, question marks, etc. Counter-counterargument: those question marks, etc. are an important \(even if optional\) part of the sentence, identifying the grammatical mood, and the <s/> elements do not contain the "edge" whitespace either.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: Ah, I wanted to add that if that premise was right, then perhaps the Guidelines could \(should?\) encourage \*replacing\* the quotation marks, which become spurious in the presence of tags. Just like the edge whitespace around <w/> and <s/> is \(in many cases at least\) spurious and can be eliminated. Whitespace is sometimes not spurious around <seg/>s for sure \(because these can identify parts of words, and YMMV wrt <w/>, if you use them for stems in compounds\); but quotation marks always \(?\) seem spurious, don't they?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text:
Piotr, I don't think you mean "spurious" \(i.e. dishonest, misleading\) but rather "superfluous" \(i.e. unnecessary, redundant\). I'm not sure that I'd agree on either interpretation in the general case though\! Knowing the kind of quote marks used is often quite important...  However, the recommendation is clear enough -- if the quote marks are retained, then they should go inside the tags, since they are more closely associated with the content of the element than with the text around it.

Kevin, yes the phrase "This section discusses the following elements, all of which are often rendered by the use of
quotation marks" definitely refers to the source document not the encoding of it. It might be worth noting in this context that the presence of quote marks is a sufficient but not necessary condition -- something could be tagged as <quote> etc even if there is no quotation mark present \(cf recent discussion with Alexei on TEI-L\)

I have now revised the text of COHQQ accordingly: please check out the revisions in sourceforge; some simpler examples would also be useful I think but I haven't added them yet.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: - **status**: open --> pending
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: I believe Lou's edits can be viewed here: http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/P5/Source/Guidelines/en/CO-CoreElements.xml?r1=7521&r2=7933&pathrev=7933 .  This change seems to contain some false positives \(due to whitespace changes\) and some copyediting unreleated to the issue at hand.  Nevertheless, Lou's substantial revisions seem clear to me.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: - **status**: pending --> open
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: Proposal is to close this ticket since no further issues have been raised.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: - **status**: open --> open-fixed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text:
Lou: thanks for the remark on the meanings of spurious/superfluous: indeed, in my private lexicon, they functioned as synonyms -- I must have acquired "spurious" already with the wrong interpretation.

I've just looked at the change \(thanks for the link, Kevin\!\), and it looks very good to me. I can also see the rationale for keeping \(superfluous :-\)\) quotation marks inside the tags.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: Closed after review by council
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

posts.text: - **status**: open-fixed --> closed-fixed

posts.subject: #230 quotation marks as character data: inside or outside tags?

tickets.summary: tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.text: your points seem good. I will work out solutions somehow.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #232 tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.text: - **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #232 tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.text:
1\. I have put a <span class="headingNumber"> around the number portion of a heading. That should provide what you need. The XSL template "formatHeadingNumber" may be useful for you too.

2\. I have done some \_drastic\_ pruning and rewriting of the way headings are done, and I believe you should now have all the power needed. each <head> will generate a <span> with a class attribute depending on whether you use @type or @rend. If I have broken a thousand other things, I shall not be surprised, but I think it is much cleaner now

3\. you might want to look at <floatingText> to cope with that embedded letter. for the headless <div>, try now <div rend='nohead'>

This is all now in Subversion only. I will make a release when I have tested it more.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #232 tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.text: - **status**: open-accepted --> closed-fixed

posts.subject: #232 tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.subject: #232 tei-to-epub - handling of division numbers and headings

posts.text:
Thanks for all those changes I'm getting the changes to the handling of the head tags as well as being able to have other span's embedded in <h..> tags. It adds enormous flexibility to the handling of the CSS.

Thanks again

Gary

posts.text:
Putting aside a "general purpose TEIpersonbase" for now, here are my proposed changes to http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/FM1.html :

= Date format =

Change all date ranges to give two digits at end to avoid confusion \(does "2002-3" mean 2002-2003 or 2002-2013?\).

= "Chair" section =

Rename this section to "Council Chair" to avoid confusion with Board chair.  Add the following people:

\* 2008-11: Laurent Romary \(Max Planck Digital Library / Inria Nancy & Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin\)
\* 2012: James Cummings \(University of Oxford\)

= Sort out "Board Members" section =

The "Board Members:" section is confusing: it's not clear who was an ex-officio member based on being Chair of the TEI and who is a member appointed by the Board.  I suggest splitting into two sections: "Board Chair" and "Members Appointed by the TEI Board".

Someone needs to figure out who should be in which list.  In addition, Lou Burnard needs to be added.  We need dates of service and affiliation\(s\) for his time.

= "Elected Members" section =

Add or modify the following in each section:

Elected Members:
\* 2011-12: Piotr Bański \(University of Warsaw\)
\* 2010-13: Brett Barney \(University of Nebraska\)
\* 2004-07: David Birnbaum \(University of Pittsburgh\)
\* 2008-13: Gabriel Bodard \(King's College London\)
\* 2008-09: Peter Boot \(Huygens Institute for Netherlands History\)
\* 2007-08: Tone Merete Bruvik \(University of Bergen\)
\* 2007-09: Arianna Ciula \(King's College London / European Science Foundation\)
\* 2005-12: James Cummings \(University of Oxford\)
\* 2002-07, 2010: Matthew Driscoll \(University of Copenhagen\)
\* 2010-13: Kevin Hawkins \(University of Michigan\)
\* 2010-13: Martin Holmes \(University of Victoria\)
\* 2010-11: Julianne Nyhan \(University of Trier / University College London\)
\* 2008-11: Elena Pierazzo \(King's College London\)
\* 2006-07, 2009-10: Dot Porter \(University of Kentucky / Digital Humanities Observatory / Indiana University\)
\* 2009-12: Sebastian Rahtz \(University of Oxford\)
\* 2002-07: Laurent Romary \(Inria / CNRS / Max Planck Digital Library\)
\* 2008-09, 2012-2013: Paul Schaffner \(University of Michigan\)
\* 2008-09: David Sewell \(University of Virginia\)
\* 2008-09: Manfred Thaller \(University of Cologne\)
\* 2005-08: John Walsh \(Indiana University\)
\* 2012-13: Rebecca Welzenbach \(University of Michigan\)
\* 2011-12: Stuart Yeates \(New Zealand Electronic Text Centre\)

\(Alejandro Bia departed in 2006 before the end of his term \(which went through December 2006\).  Did someone replace him who's not currently in FM1 or in the list above?\)

= Additions to list of Council meetings =

Revise this sentence:

In addition, the Council has held six two-day face-to-face meetings.

to say

In addition, the Council has held many face-to-face meetings.

Add the following:

\* National University of Ireland, Galway \(2008\)
\* Ecole Normale Supérieure, Lyon \(2009\)
\* Royal Irish Academy, Dublin \(2010\)
\* Big Ten Center, Chicago \(2011\)
\* Inria, Paris \(2011\)
\* University of Michigan, Ann Arbor \(2012\)

= Technical Review Committee =

A previous note in Sourceforge mentions adding a meeting of the Technical Review Committee.  Since this happened before P5, it seems it should instead be added to http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/PREFS.html .  On this page I see mention of "technical review meetings" in the early 1990s but no mention of the Kingston meeting.  Is this the same committee?  If so, it could be added there.

= Changes to other parts of the text =

Change:

The TEI Editors, Lou Burnard \(University of Oxford\) and Syd Bauman \(Brown University\) serve ex officio on the Council and, as far as possible, on all Council workgroups.

to:

From \_\_\_\_ to 2008 the TEI had two Editors, Lou Burnard \(University of Oxford\) and Syd Bauman \(Brown University\), who served ex officio on the Council and, as far as possible, on all Council workgroups.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #233 update list of Council members

posts.text:
Oh, one more thing.  Revise these sentences:

The Chair of the TEI Board sits on the Technical Council, and the Board also nominates one other member to the Council. The other Council members are all elected by the Consortium membership, and serve periods of up to two years at a time. The Board nominates the Chair of the Technical Council from among its members.

to

The Chair of the TEI Board sits on the Technical Council, and the Board appoints the Chaif of the Technical Council and one other member of the Council. Other Council members are all elected by the Consortium membership, and serve periods of up to two years at a time.

Implemented most of this at revision 10105.  You can see annotated changes here:

http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/P5/Source/Guidelines/en/FM1-IntroductoryNote.xml?r1=10105&r2=10104&pathrev=10105

Notes on what remains:

a\) Martin might still work on the "TEI personbase".

b\) Were there any Board chairs on the Council before Julia in 2004?

c\) A previous note in Sourceforge mentions adding a meeting of the Technical Review Committee.  Since this happened before P5, it seems it should instead be added to http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/PREFS.html .  On this page I see mention of "technical review meetings" in the early 1990s but no mention of the Kingston meeting.  Is this the same committee?  If so, it could be added there.

posts.subject: #233 update list of Council members

posts.text: A bit of burrowing in my email archive reveals that  minutes from a TRC meeting in Kingston in June 1997 once existed on the server at UIC, but no copy appears to have survived. The TRC was actually set up a year before this, with a meeting in Bergen in 1996. It set up a small "core committee" which met several times telephonically during 1996, and created \(inter alia\) the <ab> tag. Most of its papers survive: see www.tei-c.org/Vault/TRC/
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #233 update list of Council members

posts.text:
I'm still not clear on whether the TRC is related to the "tecnical review meetings" that supposedly happened in the early 1990s.  In any case, I now realize that http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/PREFS.html contains only prefaces from previous editions of the Guidelines, so it would be dishonest to edit this text to add to the historical record.

So while someone in Paris suggested adding the Kingston meeting to the Guidelines, I can't find an appropriate place to do so.  FM1 is all about the development of P5, and PREFS is a historical record of previously published prefaces.  I think anyone doing research can find out about this meeting in the Vault.

\(a\) and \(b\) in my previous comment still need to be resolved.

tickets.description: At present @status only allows "free" "restricted" or "unknown". It would be more useful \(now that they have done the work\) to suggest codes corresponding with the range of Creative Commons licences now available, either as possible values for @status \[but that breaks  compatibility\] or by defining a new attribute @licen\{sc\}e with values such as CCSA  CCBYND etc.

posts.text: CCSA CCBYND are insufficient for this, since the licenses have both localisations and version numbers. A full URL is the standard way of referring to them
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #234 Review possible values for @status on <availability>

posts.text: As with other TEI elements, I would expect the content of <availability> to give the fulkl details, including URL, localisation, version etc. The attribute value would just give a quick summary of the basic fact that the text is e.g. CCBY or whatever. If we agree that this is worth doiing.

tickets.description: Content model of f should permit  macro.xtext component, as shortcut for <string>

posts.text: Proposal is to permit this only with an additional schematron rule to ensure that a the content model is either plain text or a single member of model.featureVal
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text: an anonymous request with no discussion or examples? premature to resolve.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text: This would introduce an alternative encoding method for features whose values are strings.  The TEI is filled with alternative ways of encoding things, and when there aren't scholarly motivations behind them, they compound the difficulties of interchanging texts.  While using <string> as a child element makes the encoded text slightly more verbose than if macro.xtext was allowed in this element, I don't think this is a big sacrifice to make for ease of processing.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text: As Kevin says, the TEI does its best to support as many different ways of encoding as possible, even where this occasionally leads to some redundancy. We provide <pb> etc.  elements as well as <milestone>s. I don't know what's particularly "scholarly" about the motivation for that: it's just a matter of convenience isn't it? In the case under review, there is a strong  -- presumably "scholarly" -- view in some quarters that it should be possible to express the value of a feature without taking a stand as to its datatype; the fact that in practice this means that the "untyped" value is actually the same as "string" cuts no ice with that theoretical point of view. It's not just a matter of convenience: it's meeting a principled objection. I apologise for not having presented the arguments in favour of this change more clearly or more thoroughly, but I think the case is a good one. Pragmatically speaking, it would also facilitate take up of the TEI within some quarters of the language processing community, if we care about that.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text: I'd really like to see some examples and usage scenarios so I can make a decision about this. Right now, I don't see any value in this other than convenience, with the side-effect that we have two types of encoding of string features, so processing and interchange both get harder.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text:
If it doesn't cost the TEI much, it would indeed be a nice step towards full compatibility with e.g. the ISO TC 37 SC 4 type of approach, which, as Lou indicated, points out that in typical database/programming language design, data objects are kept separately from the statements of their types.

If the result can be greater synergy between SC 4 and the TEI, both of them will benefit. Indeed this seems to be a welcome step towards NLP/CL communities.

Usage scenarios could probably be dug up in or constructed from, Andreas Witt et al.'s papers on susTEInability and similar topics. But convenience in this case is also an argument: prevent NLP guys from cringing when they see <string>whatever</string> and from turning to other formalizations of feature structures :-\)
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

posts.text: Lou's context now clarifies the issue greatly.  Uses of feature structures are generally hypothetical, but I'll take his and Piotr's word for it that some people want to represent untyped data.  I no longer oppose this change.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #235 allow f to contain pcdata

tickets.description:
Currently the @evidence attribute in the att.editLike class only takes a single value of the type data.enumerated. There are certainly instances where a single intervention of editorial claim is supported by more than one from an enumerated set of evidence-types \(both internal and external support for a supplement, for example; or a date with both palaeographical and onomastic evidence. I think this attribute should allow repeatable values \(possibly even infinite?\).

This was briefly discussed on list a few months ago. I can dig out examples if that would be useful.

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard

tickets.summary: choice of schema language when using the TEI
tickets.description: CFVL \(section 23.3.2\) explains that various schema formats have different advantages and disadvantages.  I imagine that many people creating TEI documents are using <oXygen/> and are therefore capable of validating against many types of schemas.  Might we give some advice here on which to use, along the lines of http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1008&L=TEI-L&T=0&O=D&P=7612 ?  It would be good as well to know \*why\* Syd suggested using RelaxNG and Schematron in combination.

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text:
In general the TEI attempts to avoid such controversial matters as choice of programming tools, if only because information on suich things changes very rapidly. However I agree that some discussion about the differences amongst the 3 schema languages might be useful here, and will look at the text linked to above.

The need to talk about schematron is different however: we use schematron increasingly to implement restrictions which hitherto have been expressed only in the prose of the Guidelines. There is an outstanding need to review and \(where possible\) enforce all such constraints in Schematron. We also need  a common form of words to indicate  where this has been done.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text: - **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text: I'm against extending this. Its not the TEI's area of expertise, and current opinions dont belong in the Guidelines. Let those dogs sleep soundly. Has anyone been harmed by the current Guidelines?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text: I would agree with @rahtz here. If at all possible we should avoid suggesting one or other tool \(or schema language in this case\).  However, we do make wide use of RelaxNG in our content models, and so we should make sure that this is noted.  A good TEI-L topic generally though.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #238 choice of schema language when using the TEI

posts.text: Agreed that James will write a sentence to be added to Roma interface explaining choice of schema lang.

tickets.summary: Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?
tickets.description:
Tite gives little guidance on encoding lists that do not include labels and glosses -- that is, ordinary lists using bullets, numbers, or letters.  It says to refer to the TEI Guidelines, but the Guidelines give @type='ordered' for both numbered and lettered lists.  It seems uncharacteristic of Tite not to specify a way to distinguish these two different renderings.  Perhaps @rend should be recommended?

Since Tite uses <b> and <i> as syntactic sugar to save keystrokes, perhaps the same should be done for <ol> and <ul>?  We would just need to decide how these map to the values of list@type.

posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text:
<ol> corresponds with <list type="ordered"> but still doesn't tell you whether the ordering is done with numbers or letters.@rend is probably the way to do it. 
<ul> corresponds with <list type="disordered">, obviously. 
How about inline lists like \(a\) this \(b\) that and \(c\) the other?
However, I'm not sure what featureis  being requested  here.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text: This was less a  specific request and more a reminder to myself \(as Tite liason\) to work this out further in consultation with Perry Trolard and Greg Spurlock whenever I can spur them into action.  Thanks for the reminder about inline lists.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> Tite
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text:
Note that the P5 Guidelines have replaced list@type='ordered' with list@rend='numbered'.  So at this point, the suggestion would be to introduce into Tite the following syntactic sugar:

ol for list@type='numbered'
ul for list@type='bulleted'
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text:
Wouldn't the syntactic sugar be:

ol for list@rend='numbered'
ul for list@rend='bulleted'

(rather than @type)?
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text: Ah, yes, that's what I meant to write!
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

posts.text: i'd be inclined to let sleeping dogs lie with lists. if Tite has survived without shorthands for lists so far, its not a major problem?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #239 Tite: encoding of lists underspecified; syntactic sugar?

tickets.summary: Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements
tickets.description:
I have been constructing a TEI template for prosopographical records. Each record relates to a single individual. According to TEI P5 13.3.1 \(Basic Principles\), "Information about people, places, and organizations, of whatever type, essentially comprises a series of statements or assertions relating to ... traits, ..., states, ..., and events." I would like to use this organisational principle for each record and would therefore like to be able to group traits, states, and events within <person>, <place>, and <org> elements.

Accordingly, I request that the <list> element be allowed as a child of <person>, <place>, and <org> elements, and to allow traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements to be children of <list>. \(By the way, there is already a <listEvent> but it is not allowed as a child of <person>. \)

posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: Add listState as child of person, place, or org: with content model of model.stateLike|model.traitLike +
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bansp
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: - **status**: open --> pending
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text:
Not so easy: there is no model that holds just state and trait. There are three separate models:

\* http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-model.orgStateLike.html
\[state\]
\* http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-model.persStateLike.html
\[persName affiliation age education faith floruit langKnowledge nationality occupation residence sex socecStatus state trait\]
\* http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-model.placeStateLike.html
\[placeName bloc country region district settlement geogName climate location population state terrain trait\]

each of them specialized \(well, the 1st one is rather thin\). And Tim does not want to just use state and trait for the three groupings, so aren't we actually looking at

listOrgState
listPersState
listPlaceState

?

I am not sure I like the direction in which this is going, but it seems to me that this would keep to the overall organizational principles of the Guidelines, would it not?

Note also that, semantic considerations aside for a moment, these three models cannot be grouped together, because then the resulting schema is not deterministic \(state comes from three different branches\).
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: I've tried to implement this but now I'm going to withdraw all the changes, leaving Specs/listState.xml but removing all references to it, pending discussion.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: - **status**: pending --> open
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text:
So what I would like to know is:

\* whether the naming listOrgState, listPersState, listPlaceState is OK with everyone
\* whether I have green light for making listEvent a child of person, place, and org

Alternatively: do we take this to the next telco?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: Council feels that <link> and <linkGrp> pointing to @xml:id's on the <person> children provide a cleaner solution \(with potential for conflicting lists\). We should add link/linkGrp to <place> and <org> for consistency.   \(Oxford Face to Face 2012-09\)
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text:
- **milestone**: 871209 --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> open-wont-fix
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #240 Grouping traitlike, statelike, and eventlike elements

posts.text: The addition of the linking elements checked in as 11013 and 11015. Ticket ready to close.

posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #241 Add att.canonical to <faith>

posts.text: I have just realised that what I really want is for faith to have @scheme and @code, like socecStatus and occupation already do. Should I make another feature request along these lines? I would like to broaden the request to include @scheme and @code for a number of members of model.persTraitLike besides socecStatus \(i.e. age, faith, nationality, trait\) and model.persStatelike besides occupation \(affiliation, education, residence, state\). It might even make sense to add @scheme and @code to members of model.persEventLike.
posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #241 Add att.canonical to <faith>

posts.text:
y feeling is that this almost simply corrigible - <socecStatus> should not be a special case, but all members of model.persTraitLike and persStateLike should get the @code and @scheme atts for those that want to use them

It is a shame we can combine model and att classes :-\}
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #241 Add att.canonical to <faith>

posts.text:
Thevaldesc for @code and @scheme on <socectstaus> and <occupation> say that these must point to a <tei:category> and a <tei:taxonomy> respectively. Is that something that we want to carry forward if we define a new attribute class?  For consistentcy surely we'd like to be able to point to some non-TEi defined taxonomy wouldn't we?  

Also, I am having trouble thinking about what the difference between @code and @ref/@key would be in this case.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #241 Add att.canonical to <faith>

posts.text:
I think you are showing the difference between @code/@scheme, and @ref; ie the former is joined up with taxonomy and category, the latter is left vague. This leaves us in a quandary: either we take @scheme/@code off socecStatus, and give it @ref/@key, or we give @scheme/@code to its friends.

what does @scheme mean without @code anyway? why did the TEI do this two-part link?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #241 Add att.canonical to <faith>

posts.text:
It would be good to be able to point to a non-TEI defined taxonomy. It would also be good to be able to use an in-house taxonomy if there is no suitable pre-defined one.

Concerning whether @scheme + @code or @ref + @key should be used, I don't know. The more flexible the better, I suppose.

posts.text: What is the difference between @grade="circa" and @grade="about"? Why is either preferable to saying @precision = "0" \(or 0.2 or 0.3 or some other arbitrary number\)?  We introduced the datable attributes \(notBefore etc.\) to support this kind of uncertainty wrt dates, so a case might be made \(I suppose\) for attributes such as @atLeast and @atMost on numerical values but this does seem to be over-egging the pudding a bit.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text:
There is not much difference between "circa" and "about" apart from the first being used more commonly for vague dates and the second for vague quantities. However, I would not restrict allowed values for a verbal description of precision.

This is certain: saying "about" means anything but @precision = 0; the latter means that there is no precision -- the quantity is completely unknown. \(For rhetorical value, I have a physics degree.\) It is arguable that using a numeric value \(such as 0.46\)  to express a subjective judgment concerning precision \(such as implied by a word like "circa"\) is always misleading. To quote myself \(a loss of rhetorical value, but here goes\),

"For markup to be meaningful it must be reproducible. Independent encoders who are equally skilled in the art should be able to consistently arrive at the same description of the uncertainty of a given feature. This requirement immediately rules out a numerical description such as "cert=0.46." What does this description mean when the same encoder would choose a different number after lunch? Nothing\! It is meaningless and a waste of space."

\(http://purl.org/tfinney/Uncertainty/index.html\)

As for using @atLeast and @atMost, there is the problem of what, say, "c. 1740" or "about 70" means in terms of upper and lower limits. This information is lacking in many cases, so it is a better description of what the encoder has before her to just say "circa" or "about" in the accompanying description of precision.
posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text: If "there is not much difference between 'circa' and 'about'" what is the use of specifying them as attribute values? They are present in the content of the element if you want to track down the particular nuance of representation: attribute values are intended for simple minded automatic processing. How about simply saying @exact="yes" or "no" to qualify the @value value?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text:
I could live with precision/@exact provided that its datatype is data.xTruthValue. That way I could say <precision exact="unknown"/> which is a better representation of, say, a circa date's precision than something like <precision degree="0.1"/>.

If @exact with data type data.xTruthValue is added to <precision>, I beg for it to be added to other elements where the scale of uncertainty may be unknown, such as <age>, <certainty>, and relevant members of model.measureLike and model.dimLike.

Concerning utility of "about" or "circa" as attribute values, they are better descriptions than degrees such as "0.3" or "0.46" which have been pulled out of the air. I would rather say something like: 

$dodgy := count\(//someElementClass\[@exact="unknown"\]\)

than 

$dodgy := count\(xyz\)

where xyz is an expression that looks for indications of uncertainty or imprecision and keeps only those with degrees which fall into a range of \(arbitrary\) numeric values.

One reason: If numbers are ever mined from TEI produced by a number of projects, identifying dodgy numbers will be a dodgy exercise because degrees are likely to have been assigned in an arbitrary manner. 

It comes down to truth in advertising: It is better to say "I don't know how uncertain this is" than "I don't know how uncertain this is, but, because I can't easily say that, I will instead indicate the uncertainty with an arbitrary number."
posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text:
I should have thought the values we want in some new @grade/@exact attribute for non-numerical precision \(and certainty, surely\) would be the same as we currently use for @cert and @precision elsewhere; i.e. high|medium|low. \(Personally I only ever use "low" from that list, because it's enough to say "I'm a bit unsure" or "that figure is a bit imprecise/circa".

I agree with Tim that using exact \(even arbitrarily selected\) numbers when such numbers are meaningless is misleading, because such numbers \*might\* \(in other circumstances\) mean something very specific.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text: Using "high," "medium," and "low" is a good idea but I would also like to be able to say "about" for cases where that is the level of precision indicated by the text, as in a circa date. I know that "about" can mean almost anything, but people are happy with such a category in the print medium so I would like to see a corresponding grade of uncertainty in the TEI. Perhaps the alternatives \[high, medium, low, about, unknown\] would do? If adopted, it would be useful to have some guidance in the \_Guidelines\_ concerning their use. E.g. high = beyond reasonable doubt; medium = two or three viable alternatives; low = numerous possibilities; about = approximately; unknown = no indication of uncertainty.
posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text:
Council decision is to accept the need for non-numerical description of precision as documented by this ticket. \(Precision can serve two functions: \(i\) expressing precision in more specific numerical terms; \(ii\) applying the statement of precision to a specific part of the target element \[attribute, content, etc.\]. Someone who needs ii. should not be forced to use i. as well.\)

We shall implement this by adding the @precision attribute to <precision/> \(and @cert to <certainty/>, for parallelism\). This attribute will have the usual data.certainty datatype \(i.e. "high", "medium", "low", "unknown"\), partly because the value "circa" is a human-readable rather than a normalized value, but most importantly because the <precision/> element needs to be able to express the same values \(no more, no less\) as @precision.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #242 Allow non-numeric description of precision

posts.text:

tickets.summary: Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals
tickets.description:
It is sometimes necessary to describe a numerical range using a confidence interval \(e.g. 65-75\) and confidence level \(e.g. 95%\). Adding an attribute \(@conf?\) that allows a confidence level to be associated with a range would enable att.ranging to describe numerical ranges in this fashion. Values of the attribute should not be constrained. E.g.

The survey results suggested that <num min="10" max="12" conf="95%">10-12<measure type="percent">%</measure></num> would vote for the Kaos Party \(95% confidence level\).

I'm pretty sure there were <num min="20" max="30" conf="medium">20 to 30</num> of them.

posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #243 Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals

posts.text:
Sorry, I ran our of time half-way through writing the below last night. I meant to finish by asking:

Can you ever see an occasion when @conf and @cert might both be needed on the same number? Would there be problematic ambiguity between them? If not, we could perhaps change the definition of @cert to include "confidence in a numerical range", or similar.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #243 Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals

posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #243 Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals

posts.text: @cert's membership of att.responsibility indicates that it is to do with responsibility for an assertion, not confidence in the assertion. \(Also, <num> and other relevant elements don't include att.responsibility.\) Another possibility is @precision from att.dimensions. \(However, <num> and other relevant elements don't include att.dimensions.\) I would prefer @conf in att.ranging because statisticians use "confidence" rather than "certainty" when talking about such things. It would also be good for att.ranging to include @pref to identify a preferred value, whether a mean, median, mode, or something else. E.g. The survey indicates that the unemployment rate is <num type="percent" pref="15" min="12" max="18" conf="0.9">15% \(12-18%, 90% conf.\) </num>. If att.ranging included @conf \(with unconstrained values\) and @pref then I would stop complaining about this,
posts.author: tfinney
posts.subject: #243 Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals

posts.text:
Council decision is to accept the need stated in this ticket, and implement an attribute @confidence on att.ranging, with datatype data.probability \(i.e. xsd:double \{ minInclusive = "0" maxInclusive = "1" \}\), using, e.g., a value "0.95" for a confidence of 95%. We did not see the use-case for using imprecise textual values \("medium" etc.\) for this strictly mathematical attribute \(in the example given what is really being expressed is certainty\).

If the proposer wants additionally to propose the addition of a new attribute @preference, he should create a separate feature request giving the use-case for the attribute, and what datatype it would take.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #243 Allow att.ranging to express confidence intervals

tickets.description:
The element definition for <rs> includes @type but does not give any suggested values \(cf. the definition of <fw>\).  A few values are given in examplesa in the Guidelines, but sometimes seemingly simlilar concepts are expressed with different values \(such as type="org" and type="organization"\).  For ease of interchange of texts, it would be good to recommend certain values, giving explanations of what these are intended for \(as in the definition of <fw>\).

For background, see http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1009&L=TEI-L&T=0&F=&S=&P=176 .

posts.text:
I would suggest to keep in synch with existing named entity classifications, such as the widely referenced BBN classification used in evaluation conferences such as MUC.
See http://www.ldc.upenn.edu/Catalog/docs/LDC2005T33/BBN-Types-Subtypes.html

posts.text: I would agree that we can provide some suggested values, but we should probably be look at rationalising our recommendations of suggested values for @type across the guidelines as a whole.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text:
Lou has changed the instance of <rs type="organization"> in P5 to <rs type="org"> per the generally preferred way to handle syntactic sugar \(using existing element names\).  Will embellish the definition of rs@type to recommend use of http://www.ldc.upenn.edu/Catalog/docs/LDC2005T33/BBN-Types-Subtypes.html .  In addition, add a note to att.typed:

1\) giving our approach to syntactic sugar \(use the name of the sugar\)
2\) use a taxonomy in your field if it's appropriate
3\) not all elements with @type use att.typed

Kevin will implement.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text: - **status**: open-accepted --> pending-accepted
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text:
At revision 9830, modified the definition for <rs> and did \(2\) and \(3\).  However, I'm not sure how to explain \(1\).  I wanted to say:

"Alternatively, use the attribute to create syntactic sugar for another TEI element.  In this case, the value of the attribute correspond to the TEI element name.  For example, \_\_\_\_"

For the example, I thought of using name@type.  But for a personal name, do you do <name type="person"> \(corresponding to <person>\), <name type="persName"> \(corresponding to <persName>\), or <name type="pers"> \(corresponding to the "pers" in "persName"\)?
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text:
After discussion on tei-council, I see that I was misusing "syntactic sugar".  After some investigation, I see that while @type often achieves syntactic salt for an element not available in the modules chosen for a particular customization \(as is often the case with <name> or <rs>\), I can't find any members of att.typed for which this is typically the case.  That is, att.typed includes elements that are themselves already sugar or which don't seem to be sugar or salt of anything.

So I'm now inclined to skip trying to say anything about syntactic sugar for att.typed.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text: - **status**: pending-accepted --> open-accepted
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text: I agree with Kevin that there is no need to attempt to explain usage of syntactic sugar \(or salt if you prefer that rather misleading metaphor\), which was not in fact part of the original ticket. So this ticket might as well be closed.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

posts.text: - **status**: open-accepted --> closed-accepted

posts.subject: #245 provide suggested values for rs@type

tickets.description:
Inside <constraintSpec> in P5 the encoding of the names of XML constructs is inconsistent. \(As is the use of an initial capital and a trailing period.\) I believe that this should be made consistent using the standard TEI constructs: <gi>, <att>, and <val>.

Note that doing so will not break current ODD processing,although no advantage will be gained on output \(except consistency :-\). This is because currently the contents of TEI element children of Schematron elements are passed along, but the tags are dropped. But in the future properly processing these constructs could be added as a feature.

As an example, I intend to check-in a new Schematron rule added to the <app> element \(to enforce the “1-<lem>” rule expressed in prose in the <remarks> for <rdgGrp>\) which makes use of TEI phrase-level encoding of XML construct names.

posts.text: What do you mean by "inside <constraintSpec> in P5"? Are you talking about the content of the elements in the schematron namespace which <constraintSpec> contains? If so, presumably this would mean defining a  prefix for the TEI namespace and then using it? This seems a bit too much like hard work... But maybe I have misunderstood your point entirely. An example would help...
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #246 XML construct encoding within Schematron

posts.text: Your change to app has been reverted \(since it breaks the current P5 production line\) pending resolution of this issue.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #246 XML construct encoding within Schematron

posts.text:
Yes, I'm talking about the content of the elements in the schematron namespace which <constraintSpec> contains. Yes, if you declare the Schematron namespace to be the default namespace on some element inside <constraintSpec>, then you would need to somehow explicitly state that the <gi>, <att>, or <val> element was in the TEI namespace. In most, if not all, current cases in the source of the Guidelines the Schematron elements have explicit namespace prefixes, in which case no prefix or namespace declaration is required at all. That said, I don't think the details of how the namespaces are declared should change whether or not TEI properly encodes XML constructs in the source of the Guidelines.
Do you want an example other than https://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/tei/trunk/P5/Source/Specs/app.xml\#8061?
\---------
What did it break? I carefully tested the change with \`make clean validate html-web exemplars\` and explicitly checked the Schematron output — I found no problems.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #246 XML construct encoding within Schematron

posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #246 XML construct encoding within Schematron

posts.text:
Ah, indeed. Syd's URL showed &lt; and &gt; to me, but the modification is more clearly visible at

http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/P5/Source/Specs/app.xml?revision=8061&view=markup
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #246 XML construct encoding within Schematron

tickets.summary: non-inline notes: where to put the <note>?
tickets.description: Tite implies that notes should not be encoded inline \(as is preferred TEI practice\) but rather with <ptr> or <ref> elements pointing to the <note> elements found elsewhere.  However, Tite doesn't specify where to put the <note> in the XML. This should be clarified.

posts.text: You could also review the decision not to encode notes inline, of  course. However, if you want to stick with it, then the obvious place is in a separate <div type="notes"> within the <back>
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #248 non-inline notes: where to put the <note>?

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #248 non-inline notes: where to put the <note>?

posts.text: Oops, Tite says, "Transcribe the note directly after it is referenced in the document. In the case of notes without explicit reference \(pointed to with ptr\), set the anchored attribute to false."  That is, you have <ref> or <ptr/> followed immediately by a <note>.  I assume the reasoning here was that you need <ref> to include a transcription of the siglum or <ptr/> to explicitly indicate that the point of attachment is inferred to be at this location.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #248 non-inline notes: where to put the <note>?

tickets.description: Lou and Sebastian think it would be a good idea to roll Tite-specific elements into the TEI namespace.  Kevin thinks this would have the extra benefit of not having the TEI maintain two namespaces, which leads those using a Tite schema to need to invent at least one namespace prefix in order to tell the validator where to find the elements.

posts.text:
Sebastian wrote on tei-council:

I think that Lou probably meant to say "drop some of the sillier extensions in Tite and merge in the rest". So looking at new elements

ident="cols"
\* add
ident="sub"
\* add
ident="sup"
\* add
ident="ornament"
\* add

ident="b"
ident="i"
ident="smcap"
ident="ul"

these remain \_so\_ much syntactic sugar that I'd be very reluctant to add them.  is it really so very hard to simply constrain <hi> to allow only these values on @rend?
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: The principle is sound. But, as Kevin quotes me, I find the synonyms for <hi rend='xxx'> hard to stomach. I propose instead that @rend pn <hi> be a fixed list in Tite.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: Note that if we decide not to merge these namespaces, it would be a good idea for Tite to mandate use of a DTD rather than other schema type by any vendor charging for delivered files by the byte.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: I think that providing a fixed set of values for  the @rend attribute on <hi> makes more sense than defining tite:smcap etc , but I can live with either or both. If I ever actually said that we might  add <smcap> to the TEI namespace I was clearly raving. I don't understand the comment on "mandating use of a DTD rather than other schema type" below -- there isn't any obvious way of doing such a thing and it doesn't seem relevant to this ticket.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> Tite
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text:
Obviously the TEI Consortium cannot and should not attempt to restrict anyone's use of our schemas or documentation beyond the restrictions on the GNU license.  However, since Tite is designed for use by vendors and discusses things such as accuracy of keyboarding, I believe it would also be appropriate for Tite to discuss things that can affect the number of characters used in the encoding: namely, the use of namespaces for TEI elements.  Since vendors often charge by the byte, the size of the file can vary greatly depending on where and how namespaces are specified.  To me the most sensible way to enforce uniformity and keep the byte count to a minimum is to require a vendor to use the DTD, not one of the various schema formats, avoiding namespaces entirely.

You might say this is something for a vendor and customer to negotiate, but the point of Tite is to provide something ready to use for customers and vendors who don't want to have to go through all of this on their own.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: Renaming this ticket to reflect what was actually suggested: rolling relevant parts of the Tite Guidelines, not necessarily Tite-specific elements.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

posts.text: - **summary**: roll Tite-specific elements into TEI namespace --> roll Tite into TEI P5
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #249 roll Tite into TEI P5

tickets.summary: content of <subst> does not permit globals
tickets.description:
The content model of <subst> is currently 
\_\_\( \( model.pPart.transcriptional \), model.pPart.transcriptional+ \)
which makes it difficult to encode a substitution for which the deletion occurred before, but the addition occurred after, a milestone of some sort, say a column break. It also makes it impossible to encode an editorial note inside the <subst> \(although it could, of course, but put elsewhere with a target=\).

Perhaps the content model should be something like the following. I am a bit hesitant as I have not tried to think through the implications. E.g., what does it mean if an <addSpan> is inside a <subst>, but it's other end is an <anchor> outside the <subst>? What does it mean if there is a <figure> inside a <subst>? \(Since <figure> is allowed, why not <eg>?\)

\_\_\( model.global\*, \( model.pPart.transcriptional, model.global\* \), \( model.pPart.transcriptional, model.global\* \)+ \)

posts.text: This should be addressed along with fr \#2859355
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #251 content of <subst> does not permit globals

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #251 content of <subst> does not permit globals

posts.text: This should be addressed along with fr \#2859355
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #251 content of <subst> does not permit globals

posts.text:
The Council subgroup discussing the content model of tei:subst considered one of the propositions suggested in this ticket. Although we decided to recommend that text and other element not be introduced to the content model of tei:subst, it was proposed that an exception be made for tei:lb \(and other milestoneLike elements\), for the case where a substitution is made inline in a draft manuscript, and the addition happens to appear on the line \(column, page, etc.\) after the deletion.

\(I was uncomfortable with this, but the group was otherwise unanimous in approval.\)

We therefore recommend that milestoneLike elements be added to the content model of tei:subst. \(But cf. tickets http://purl.org/TEI/FR/3393244 and http://purl.org/TEI/FR/2859355 in which it is recommended that the content model of tei:subst be restricted to add and del, at least in guidance.\)
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #251 content of <subst> does not permit globals

posts.text: Now replaced by 3393244

tickets.description:
http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-availability.html

Currently the note says: 
"A consistent format should be adopted "

I would suggest, given recent discussions \(2010-10-13\) on TEI-L that at very least we might want to clarify the distinction between 'free' and 'restricted'.  \(Even though, I note, the example does this perfectly clearly, people are still confused about it.\)

A couple options:
1\) Perhaps rephrase the note along the lines of: 
"If encoding multiple resources a consistent format for availability information should be adopted.  The status attribute should be used to differentiate between resources entirely in the public domain and those with any form of IPR restriction \(such as a particular license\)."

2\) Change the attribute values  \(open/closed, free/restricted/licensed, and other suggestions have all been made.\)


It would be good to re-examine <availability> in light of developments in Rights Expression Languages to see if:
a\) TEI wishes to recommend some specific XML-based language in its own namespace
b\) TEI wishes to create its own general-purpose Rights Expression module
c\) TEI wishes to add @target to <availability> to give a defined way to point to a machine-readable expression of rights \(in whatever format\)
d\) TEI wishes definitely not to do none of these and leave <availability>'s content as model.pLike


-James

posts.text: The ticket contains complex aspects related to our rights policy. In anycase, I would support the idea of offering @target as a means to point to whatever reference there is around \(and would probably take CC as an example, since many projects may want to refer to it\).
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #252 Expand note on <availability>

posts.text: I vote for c\).
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #252 Expand note on <availability>

posts.text: Adding @target to <availability> doesn't seem right to me -- If anything I'd expect this rather to be where the object was available from. I think what's needed is some substructure to <availability> e.g. a <licen\{cs\}e> child which could then point to the applicable licence info, or contain it. Then you could have multiple licences -- which does happen. And you could retain the current loose prose, as elsewhere in the Header.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #252 Expand note on <availability>

posts.text:
Lou's objections actually talk me round in this case, however, prompt another suggestion.

I would much prefer a license child with att.typed and att.pointing \(containing what? macro.paraContent?\)

So assuming that we don't want to develop a fully complete rights expression language or recommend some specific vocabulary, what about changing content model of availability to be:

1\) model.pLike+ as it is now
2\) model.pLike+ or tei:licence+ \(which is member of att.typed and att.pointing containing macro.paraContent\)
3\) same as 2 but instead it contains model.pLike \(for multiple embedded licence paragraphs\)
4\) model.pLike+ or tei:ptr+
5\) Something else I've not thought of...

-j
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #252 Expand note on <availability>

posts.text:
Council agreed to:
\- define new <licence> element 
\- use @target on <licence> to reference existing licence agreement
\- use @datable attributes on <licence> to indicate dates of its applicability
\- use content of <licence> to specify any additional conditions, or quote the whole agreement
All the <licence> elements within a given <availability> are considered applicable to the whole document. If parts of a document have different conditions, different <availability>s should be supplied, and selected by means of the @decls attribute.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #252 Expand note on <availability>

tickets.description: Change the name of musicNotation <http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-musicNotation.html> in model.physDescPart to something more in keeping with its semantics. To be more similar to other elements in model.physDescPart, the element could be renamed musicNotationDesc \(preferred\) or musicDesc.

posts.text: I don't think <musicDesc> would be appropriate, since this element does not describe the music \(=performance\) but rather the way it's notated in this manuscript. I can see the argument therefore for <musicNotationDesc> though this is quite a mouthful and would cause problems for existing documents. If part of the rationale is to allow for <musicNotation> to be used elsewhere with some other semantics, that would further confound the confusion, so I would much prefer to leave this particular sleeping doc snoozing.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

posts.text:
Dear Lou,

You make an important point. Renaming would cause backward compatibility problems and using <musicNotation> elsewhere could cause further confusion. However, we do see a need for marking the position of music notation within the text and allow for a description in place and pointers to external objects/representations \(as suggested in FR 3086726\). Although <musicNotation> would have been a good element name in this case, we are suggesting <musicalNotation> as alternative, since "music notation" and "musical notation" are synonyms, as it is evident from several sources, including the OED under "notation" 6.a.\(b\)
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

posts.text:
In the other ticket tei:music has now been settled on because it has the possibility of embedding all forms of music rather than just notation.  Does this change the opinions on what to call this element?  Remembering, of course, that this element is still embedded in the manuscript description metadata and so it is very unlikely for this to contain real 'music' rather than musicNotation.  \(Immediately a potential use case springs to mind where I handwrite a birthday card manuscript which also contains embedded in it one of those annoying musical recordings when opened.  \*shudder\*  Let's pretend I didn't mention that.\)

I would still argue for musicNotationDesc however much of a mouthful so that the element comes in parallel with all the other \*Desc elements inside physDescPart.

-James
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

posts.text: Closed: element is now called notatedMusic
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #253 Rename musicNotation

tickets.description:
Add a new element to mark the presence of music notation, describe it and point to an external representation and/or embed an XML-based representation. Possible names are musicNotation \(if request \#3086720 is accepted\) or musicalNotation, etc. 

Module and Classes: 
Music notation embedded within text is usually treated like a figure; therefore this new element should be part of the "figures" module and part of model.global. 

Attribute Classes: 
In addition to att.global it would be a member of att.typed and att.placement as this would allow basic classification \(@type='rhythmic-pattern'; 'example'; 'movement'; 'full-piece'\) as well as indication of whether the music is located above/below/interspersed between the text being transcribed. 

Content: 
To allow a description of the music notation, the element should contain model.glossLike. Moreover, to give the possibility of pointing to external representations, the element should contain model.ptrLike.

posts.text: In addition to model.glossLike this should have model.graphicLike in its content model to allow <graphic/> and especially <binaryObject/> for those who \(for whatever weird reason\) want to embed base64 encoded binary audio music representations or similar.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text:
As a consequence of the TEI Music SIG Meeting at TEIMM 2010 on November 12, the proposal is update as follows:

Element name: music

Module and Classes: as above

Attribute Classes: as above, plus a type attribute with two recommended values: notation and sound

Contet: as above
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: @James, I really like the idea, especially for <binaryObject/> but I wonder what are the consequences of having <graphic/> there. Could that be used to embed an image of a score? Should <music> be preferred over <figure/> in that case? Is this desirable?
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text:
Yes, as we've discussed a proposed tei:music element is a figureLike element so should indeed have the ability to have a graphic in it.  I feel that a tei:music/@type='notation' with a graphic element inside it would be a form of syntatic sugar for embedding a figure with a graphic pointing to a score.  It would just be a more precise way of doing so and also allows for instead embedding MEI or something else, or indeed tei:binaryObject with a recording.  

This makes it a much more general purpose element for denoting that some bit of the original here had music in some sense, which I think is a much more flexible approach.  But I tend to fall into the if in doubt make it more general purpose and flexible camp rather than the if in doubt make it as tight as possible camp.

-james
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: I am on James' camp there. It sometimes takes ages to try to mend a too narrow model when people have started to adopt it.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: Thanks everyone for your input on the feature request\! Ok, I see your point in making the model more general. And if the FR 3113682 is accepted, then we also solve the problem with mime types that we were discussing on the Music SIG list.  See: http://bit.ly/muSIG\_mimetype
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text:
After some more discussion on the TEI-MUSIC-SIG list, we would like to suggest a tag name that brings us back to our original aim: marking the presence of music notation in text. Please consider this latest update:

Element name: notatedMusic
Member of: model.global
Attribute classes: att.typed; att.placemnt
Content: \{ \(model.glossLike|model.ptrLike|binaryObject|graphic\)\* \}
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: notatedMusic has already been added.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #254 Add element for music notation

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

tickets.summary: Minor change to clarify the usage of <date> inside <imprint>
tickets.description:
We should revise the first sentence of COBICOI \(section 3.11.2.3\)
from

By imprint is meant all the information relating to the publication of a
work: the person or organization by whose authority and in whose name a
bibliographic entity such as a book is made public or distributed \(whether
a commercial publisher or some other organization\), the place of
publication, and a date

to

By imprint is meant all the information relating to the publication of a
work: the person or organization by whose authority and in whose name a
bibliographic entity such as a book is made public or distributed \(whether
a commercial publisher or some other organization\), the place of
publication, and the date of publication.

i.e. adding the last two words.

This suggestion by Kevin Hawkins arose as part of another ticket \(\#2987832, http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=2987832&group\_id=106328&atid=644065\), and has been split off into its own ticket for simplicity's sake. The original ticket gives the context for the suggestion, with a discussion about the meaning of <imprint>, and of <date> within it \(as opposed to elsewhere in a <biblStruct>\).

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
- **status**: open --> open-accepted

posts.text: I would like to see these added to the TEI, as described in the Genetic WG document. I would very much like to see also recommendations for stand-off document-centric markup, but that is a separate issue.
posts.author: dot_porter
posts.subject: #257 New <document> <patch> <line> elements for genetic view

posts.text:
There's a minor parallel structure issue with the suggested values for patch/@binder:

<http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/Council/Working/tcw19.html\#patch>

Sample values include: 	

glue
patch is glued in place
pin
patch is pinned or stapled in place
sewn
patch is sewn in place 

"glue" and "pin" are nouns, while "sewn" is a past participle. I think there are two alternatives:

Sample values include: 	

glued
patch is glued in place
pinned
patch is pinned or stapled in place
sewn
patch is sewn in place 

OR

Sample values include: 	

glue
patch is glued in place
pin
patch is pinned or stapled in place
stitching
patch is sewn in place 

Also, it's interesting that @height and @width are here specified in mm, whereas in other contexts \(<binaryObject>, <graphic>\) they're data.outputMeasurement, which allows for a full range of measurement types and units. I can envisage a situation in which only an image of an object exists, and its physical scale is not clear, so it might be necessary to specify width and height in \(say\) pixels.

posts.subject: #257 New <document> <patch> <line> elements for genetic view

tickets.summary: New elements to document stages in the writing process
tickets.description:
New <stageNotes> within the existing <creation> element containing new <stageNote> elements to document identified "writing stages" in 
genesis of a text. New att.staged class to supply @stage attributes for elements which can be assigned to a given writing stage.  These allow marked up elements to be assigned to particular stages in  the genesis of a text, or the writing of a document, or both\!

Justification, element specs, and examples are in the Genetic WG document at http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/Council/Working/tcw19.html \(derived from http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/genetic/\)

posts.text: I'm sure this has been voiced before, and probably answered, but it's not on the SF ticket so I'll raise it anyway: I'm a little uncomfortable with the use of "stage" in a context where it might be confused with its meaning in the context of drama. Wouldn't <phaseNotes> be better?
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #259 New elements to document stages in the writing process

posts.text:
I'd second Martin's wariness here.  The first comment I made when reading the genetic draft was about possible confusion with the term of text revision 'stages'.  I'm not saying I'd vote for 'phase' but I've not got a better solution.

-j
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #259 New elements to document stages in the writing process

posts.text: Well. In the publishing environment we do speak about stages \(acceptance, revision, etc.\), and it makes me think that we would need such an element more generally in the header to represent such publishing stages. There's been several discussions on the list about this issue and I don't remember being made happy by the ultimate proposal on this topic.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #259 New elements to document stages in the writing process

posts.text: I would suggest that the term 'workflow' be used \(see https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/Workflow \). As a neologism it suffers from less ambiguity than 'stages' or 'phases'
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #259 New elements to document stages in the writing process

posts.text: After extensive discussion on council including two rather inconclusive votes, the name "layer" seems to have prevailed \(attribute @layer, elements <layer>, and <listLayer>\).  See draft doc at http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/Council/Working/tcw21.html
