tickets.description:
Section 4.3.2 \(\#DSFLT\) discusses floating texts and gives an example of a frame story that contains stories within the frame story.  This seems to me to be different from a situation where the frame story \*quotes\* a whole text.  I bring this up because this section ends with the following: "The floatingText element should only be used for complete texts which form a part of the text being encoded. Where a character in one narrative quotes from some other text or narrative, fully or in part, the quote  element discussed in 3.3.3 Quotation  should be used instead."  I read this as saying that, if you quote an entire text, you should not use <quote> with a nested <floatingText> element but use only <quote>.  It seems to me that it would be ontologically correct to include both <quote> and the nested <floatingText>, even in the examples given -- after all, a character in one narrative quotes from some other text or narrative, no?

An additional reason to make it clear that you should use <quote><floatingText> even when quoting entire texts is that, if you use only <quote> \(as above\), you are limited by the content model of <quote> in what structure you can tag within the quoted passage.

posts.text: One way of looking at the difference is that <floatingText> is for intrusions into the structure, whereas <quote> is for passages which fit within the structure. They have different content models as a consequence. There's no reason why a floating text should not contain quotes of course, but the reverse does not make much sense to me, except for the rather special case where one is citing the Guidelines discussion of this point\!
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: cf \#3106834 on a similar point
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
Lou wrote, "There's no reason why a floating text should not contain quotes of course,
but the reverse does not make much sense to me, except for the rather
special case where one is citing the Guidelines discussion of this point\!"

I think we can all agree that a <floatingText> could contain more than one <quote> within it.  That was never in debate.  And I'm not sure what exactly the special case is and how it matters for "the reverse", which I take to refer to is putting <floatingText> within <quote>.  Let me restate my problem with section 4.3.2.

It seems to me that if "a character in one narrativce quotes from some other text or narrative" IN FULL, then you should have a single <floatingText> within <quote>.  However, section 4.3.2 currently says to use only <quote>, which constrains the types of elements you would use here.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
Discussion at the Council meeting in Chicago and on tei-council since then has yielded a proposal to replace the final paragraph in section 4.3.2 \(\#DSFLT\) with the following:

The semantics of <quote> imply that its content emanates from somewhere external to the current text. The <floatingText> element, on the other hand, is used whenever the richer content model it provides is required to support mark up of a  document or part of a document which is presented as a discrete inclusion within the text. Such an inclusion might resemble an enclosure or an attachment, or an embedded story within a framing narrative, or simply appear as an explicit quotation. Hence the two elements may be used in combination: a <floatingText> may appear within a <quote>, and may also of course include a <quote> as part of its own structure.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: Actually, I prefer Lou's original here. I think we were trying to make the point \(among others\) that if a floatingText is a quotation, it should appear within a quote tag, and the original "appear within  an explicit quotation" makes this a little clearer. I may be misunderstanding the import of your emendation, though.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
Martin refers to the penultimate proposal for that paragraph, which had "or appear within  an explicit quotation" instead of "or simply appear as an explicit quotation" as in my most recent comment.  I think Lou was speaking about the <floatingText> element, whereas I was speaking about a floating text.

But Martin is right that Lou's version more explicitly avoids the confusion that led to this ticket in the first place.  Since it's not clear whether "the inclusion" refers to <floatingText> or a floating text, let's go with Lou's version but keep "simply" since this is the most basic and common type of floating text and since it makes the sentence easier to read.  That is, here's our text to replace the final paragraph in section 4.3.2
\(\#DSFLT\):

The semantics of <quote> imply that its content emanates from somewhere
external to the current text. The <floatingText> element, on the other
hand, is used whenever the richer content model it provides is required to
support mark up of a document or part of a document which is presented as
a discrete inclusion within the text. Such an inclusion might resemble an
enclosure or an attachment, or an embedded story within a framing
narrative, or simply appear within an explicit quotation. Hence the two
elements may be used in combination: a <floatingText> may appear within a
<quote>, and may also of course include a <quote> as part of its own
structure.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
Further discussion on tei-council yields the following two paragraphs to replace the final paragraph of in section 4.3.2 \(\#DSFLT\):

It is important to distinguish the use of <floatingText> and <quote>. Whereas the semantics of <quote> imply that its content emanates from somewhere external to the current text, <floatingText> does not imply this. The <floatingText> element is simply used whenever the richer content model it provides is required to support mark up of a text or part of a text which presented as a discrete inclusion within the text. Such an "inclusion" might consist of a text that is perceived as external to the document, such as a letter, enclosure, or attachment, but it might equally well be a text that is not external to the document, such as the text of a "musical number" that is clearly set off from its surrounding text in the libretto of an opera.

The two elements may be used in combination: a <floatingText> may appear within a <quote> \(when a text wich rich internal structure is quoted at length\), and <floatingText> may also include one or more <quote> elements as part of its own structure, just like any text.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: Sorry, I have a problem with this latest version. It explicitly introduces the case of an embedded musical number, for which we have another proposal on the table \(but not yet discussed\). I fear we have to defer this until we have looked at 3147225
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: Since the reference to musical numbers is purely illustrative, this should not differ the resolution of this ticket, could be replace by "structured legal statement" for instance.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
- **milestone**: 871209 --> 686585
- **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: - **milestone**: 686585 --> GREEN
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
Since 3147225  has been resolved to handle musical numbers, our new version \(with some additional copyediting done here and more to be done by Brett\) is:

It is important to distinguish the use of <floatingText> and <quote>.
Whereas the semantics of <quote> imply that its content emanates from
somewhere external to the current text, <floatingText> does not imply this.
The <floatingText> element is simply used whenever the richer content model
it provides is required to support mark up of a text or part of a text
which is presented as a discrete "inclusion" within the text. Such an
inclusion might consist of a text that is perceived as external to the
text, such as a letter, enclosure, or attachment.

The two elements may be used in combination: a <floatingText> may appear
within a <quote> \(when a text wich rich internal structure is quoted at
length\), and <floatingText> may also include one or more <quote> elements
as part of its own structure, just like any text.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: kshawkin --> brettbarney
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
My proposal: 

It is important to distinguish between the uses of <floatingText> and <quote>. Whereas the semantics of <quote> suggest that its content derives from a source external to the current text, <floatingText> carries no such implication and is simply used whenever the richer content model that it provides is required to support the markup of a part of a text that is presented as a discrete "inclusion." In some cases, such inclusions could be considered external \(e.g., enclosures, attachments, etc.\); often however, as in the examples above, the included text bears no signs of emanating from outside.

<floatingText> and <quote> may be used in combination. For a text with rich internal structure that is quoted at length, <floatingText> might be used within <quote>. Also, like a unitary text, <floatingText> may include one or more quoted sections, each marked with a <quote> element.
posts.author: brettbarney
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text: - **status**: open-accepted --> closed-accepted
posts.author: brettbarney
posts.subject: #260 <quote><floatingText>

posts.text:
I agree that this could potentially be rephrased. I think the intent behind the warning is that it is for wholly separate texts embedded in the host text , rather than caring whether that wholly embedded text is originally fragmentary or not.  That is, if you are just quoting a bit of text \(however long\) then the various q/quote elements are appropriate.  If you are embedding a text \(or I would argue possible a full division of text\) where you've included it in full but it itself is frgmentary, then floatingText still seems appropriate.  If I now quoted the 3rd paragraph from the 1st chapter of the TEI P1 guidelines here, then that is quote.  If I verbatim included the whole chapter as a for of embedded text that would be floatingText, if the \*sole surviving copy\* of TEI P1 chapter 1 only had the first two-thirds of it, then that would still be floatingText.  At least that has always been my understanding of it, others mileage may very.

-James
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: I suppose the word "complete" could be removed, or replaced with "distinct"? I think the intention is fairly clear, that floatingText is for things which have their own structure.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: Using floatingText for things which have their own structure is quite sensible to me, but such an intention was not at all clear to me from the current prose of the Guidelines.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: cf \#3106829 which seems to be on a similar point
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: The resolution of FR 3106829 obviates the need to address this since the offending statement will be replaced by one that allows you to use <floatingText> to "support mark up of a text or part of a text".  Closing the ticket.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #261 floatingText for incomplete texts

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-later

tickets.summary: make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia
tickets.description:
In some cases when using ptr and ref to link to remote locations, since @target takes a URI this may be pointing to all sorts of different mimeType files on the internet. There are numerous possible cases where one might be tempted to abuse the @type attribute \(which refers to the type of ptr not the type of resource pointed at\).  The proposal is to add ptr and ref to att.internetMedia which would give them a @mimeType attribute.

-James

posts.text: I have a strong feeling, that this is an important move. I fully support.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: Can you give some use cases where you'd make use of this? the URI you  hit will report its mimeType, after all, if you ask it. This worries me as having the potential to introduce contradiction
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> rahtz
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: I'm far from being an expert on such transactions, so please treat me gently ;-\) but isn't it important to state what MIME type you expect on this end, independently of what the URI is able to report \(depending on the skill of the one who set up the server\).
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
oh you mean the mimeType is a request \(for content negotiation\), not
a description? interesting. Does anyone have a suggestion about how you would actually use this, then?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
Sorry, I still don't get it.

When you say 
<ptr target="happybirtday.xml"
mimeType="application/vnd.recordare.musicxml"/>

what are you saying, in human speak? is it
a\) if you get that file, its content will be that mimetype
or
b\) get the musicxml version of  that file

I don't think you can use the same attribute for both?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
It supplies the mime type \(when applicable\) of the object specified by the @target attribute. I think that means a\) if you get that file, its content will/should be that mimetype.
At application level, it could be useful to -for example- reject that file if it doesn't report the specifiec mimetype.
posts.author: rviglianti
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
I have a feeling that resolving this ticket requires making the meaning of @mimeType\[1\] precise. And possibly even switching the request from using @mimeType to some new attribute, say @mimeAccept, as mentioned in ticket \#3284811 \[2\]. 

Because @mimeType makes sense as a pure MIME type description for <graphic> and such, whereas here, it makes much more sense to make <ptr> and <ref> use an Accept-type string, because they are likely to contain fragment identifiers, and fragment identifiers only make sense for specific MIME types -- each MIME type potentially defines the syntax of fragment identifiers, so I think we may sometimes want to request a specific MIME type \(with possible fallbacks\) when pointing into some resource, and to potentially reject it, if there is no match, as Raffaele suggests.

\[1\]: http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-att.internetMedia.html
\[2\]: https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&atid=644065&aid=3284811&group\_id=106328
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: Following up on a conversation with James, I agree that the priority is to make this available for the users, with the issue of context-dependent interpretation \(description vs. request\) to be possibly fine-tuned at a later time.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: Council agreed that ptr and ref shd be added to att.internetMedia, which has been implemented as of rev 8833 ...  discussion of usage and example still needed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: rahtz --> louburnard
- **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text:
"Discussion of usage and example" still needs to be added, but it's waiting for resolution of bug 3400825, which will change the status of @mimeType from "mandatory when applicable" to "optional". There are also a couple of outstanding questions regarding URIs pointing to fragments -- what mime type could/should be applied to fragments like this:

<ptr target="http://www.w3.org/TR/xptr-xpointer/\#xpointer\(id\('chum'\)/quote\)"/>
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

posts.text: xmlfragments get mimetype of xml:tei -- that's what we expect to receive. tho obviously it's up to the server to decide.

posts.subject: #262 make ptr & ref  member of att.internetMedia

tickets.description:
Coming back to a discussion within ms-sig \(http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0907&L=TEI-MS-SIG&P=R34\) I would like to ask for revision of <altIdentifier> as child of <msPart>: <altIdentifier> cannot have <altIdentifier> as children which might be needed if a part of a manuscript has its own name. Example for this are the catalogues of E.A. Lowe \(CLA\) which list msParts as separate catalogue entries. The catalogue numbers would have to be encoded using <altIdentifier type="catalog">. Thus, <altIdentifier> should be available at least as child within <altIdentifier>?

I think it would even better --though I know that I ask for "breaking documents"-- to rename <altIdentifier> as child of <msPart> into something like <msPartIdentifier> in analogy to <msIdentifier>\!?

posts.text: In the case you cite, if each msPart has its own catalogue entry, I don't understand why you cannot use <altIdentifier> within <msPart> for it: could you give more detail of the example? Or do you mean that each part has more than one identifier? This seems unlikely\!
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #264 altIdentifier in msPart

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #264 altIdentifier in msPart

posts.text: Consider a composite ms; if I want to enter a \*new\* description, I will identify the parts within msPart by using altIdentifier. Now, these parts already have another identifier, a catalogue number, here in the CLA. But I'm not allowed to use altIdentifier within altIdentifier but this would be needed if we want to build the msPart-Identifier in analogy to msIdentifier. \(Important: I don't want to encode the description of Lowe, this would be easy using different msDesc, but I only want to "cite" the number of the catalogue.\)

posts.subject: #264 altIdentifier in msPart

posts.text: Council agreed to make <msIdentifier> available within <msPart> as an alternative to <altIdentifier> and to deprecate the latter usage. This is implemented at rev 8828, but some examples are needed.

tickets.summary: add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts
tickets.description:
Tite is missing both <add> and <del>.  These are needed to support encoding of handwritten source material.  The member survey that led to Tite detected a desire for vendor encoding of manuscripts, and it was an oversight not to include this in Tite.

In addition to adding them to the schema, some prose documentation will need to be written and inserted into the prose at an appropriate location.

posts.text: if you have <add> and <del>, don't you need <choice>, <sic>, <corr> etc as well? not to mention <addSpan> and <delSpan>.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text:
I asked for comments from Council on this by today but hadn't noticed Sebastian's comment.  Sorry about that.

I believe the reason for including on <add> and <del> but not <sic> or <corr> is that a vendor would only want to determine what was added or deleted but not make determinations of which is correct.  You can also make do without <choice> \(like we did before P5\).  As for <addSpan> and <delSpan>, these would be useful in cases where an addition or deletion spans some other element to be tagged, but it also complicates things for the vendor.  I imagine vendors would prefer to start and stop an <add> or <del> on each side of the intervening tag, and maybe this would be good enough for clients as well.  Might need to think about this some more.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> Tite
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text:
In recent discussion on the tei-council list, Sebastian wrote:

If the Tite users want <add> and <del>, sure, go and ahead and give it to them. \[. . .\] If Tite plans to cover hand-written material, I personally think that's such a huge extra burden that the advantages of a standardized Tite are negligible. I think I'd prefer a TiteMS, which is Tite + Handwrititing, rather than giving <add> and <del> to the vast majority of Tite users.

And James wrote:

Though there may have been a desire for vendor encoding of manuscripts, this comes with so much overhead that makes Tite as it is unsuitable. \(I.e. if we were making TiteMS then there are a lot more things I'd add rather than just add/del.\)  I would suggest that where manuscripts are concerned a bespoke customisation be agreed with the vendor \(this could be Tite + add/del, or entirely different\).
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text: Apex added <add> and <del> but not <sic>, <corr>. and <choice>.  Vendors are trying to make as few interpretations as possible.  They have not added <addSpan> and <delSpan>, though this is probably just because they haven't needed them yet.  Need to consider adding <addSpan> and <delSpan> as well.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text: Added <add> and <del> at revision 9559.  Keep this ticket open for consideration of <addSpan> and <delSpan>.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

posts.text: Even without working with manuscripts, and confining ourselves largely to capturing books as printed, we found the need in TCP to add ADD DEL and CHOICE (the latter confined to a limited content model of ADD DEL ABBR EXPAN). These tend to make things easier for vendors, not harder, since they allow a ready way to capture hand-corrected or hand-deleted books for which there is no other obvious mechanism open to the vendors.
posts.author: pfschaffner
posts.subject: #267 add <add> and <del> for encoding of manuscripts

tickets.description: In Tite, @facs is missing as an attribute on <pb/>.  This is needed to indicate the correspondence between page images and encoded text.  Some prose giving instructions on how to use this attribute should also be added.

posts.text: It's obviously an essential thing to have for any project requiring a basic link between text and image. +1
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: Hearing no objections from Coucil, consider this adopted.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: In canonical TEI, @facs is globally available, if you add it. That might \(or might not\) be desirable for Tite, methinks.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: Lou. Need a clear statement. Are you suggesting to use @facs globally \(as in mainstream P5\) to implement this ticket. If yes, and with approval of Kevin, we can move ahead.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text:
What about re-adding @facs \*just\* to pb.  Although this means it is maintained outside the class system, it doesn't break conformance \(as long as it is a clone of the @facs that tei:pb would get anyway in tei\_all\).

I would be against adding @facs globally in Tite but in favour of adding it just to tei:pb.  The point of Tite is to be a highly constrained version of TEI which mass-digitizers are able to target their processes towards.  I think having it globally fights against that.  We don't want Tite edging towards becoming Lite.  With Tite I'd prefer to err on the side of excluding things frankly, rather than including them.
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text:
I think the real point of Tite is to provide a constrained version of TEI suitable for encoders, who want exactly one way to encode any textual feature they might encounter.

From what I can tell, the vision here is to use pb@facs to point to a page image but graphic@url to point to an image of something smaller than a page.  So we only need @facs on pb.  In line with James's reasoning, we should only add where needed even if this would go against the class model in P5.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text:
I've no problem with the idea of saying that only <pb> should get @facs in lite, but the point of my comment was that it is not obvious how to avoid other things getting it too. In general, I think "cloning" attributes is not good practice, so it would be a useful exercise to see whether it is now possible to make just one element in a schema inherit from a supposedly global class. That was after all one of the purposes of the changes made for release 1.9 

In response to Kevin's comment on the ticket: there is a big difference between pb@facs and graphic@url -- the latter means that there is an image here which forms \*part of the text\* -- the former means that there is an image of this part of the text here, but it is not a textual constituent.

I'm also a bit surprised to learn that data capture agencies want to use this feature: are they going to be supplying page images too? If so, shouldn't we be going the whole hog and adding <facsimile> and <surface> \(at least\) as well?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: Lou's explanation of the distinction between pb@facs and graphic@url is a more precise way of describing what I was trying to say.  That is, pb@facs is to be used to point to a facsimile of the whole page \(which is either provided to the vendor as the source of their work or is created by the vendor by scanning from the source document\), whereas graphic@url is used to point to an figure that appears in the text.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> Tite
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text:
if you want @facs just on <pb> \(sure, why not, if the users need this\), then

a\) remove membership of att.global in class att.global.facs
b\) make pb an explicit member of att.global.facs

and you should be done.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: Turns out this was already done at revision 8764, which, despite the confusing Subversion commit message, is when Lou implemented ticket 3136934.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.subject: #268 add @facs to <pb/>

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> Tite

posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: Implemented at https://sourceforge.net/p/tei/code/13088/ .  Will email Sebastian to ask him to update tei-xsl package accordingly.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text:
- **status**: open --> closed-fixed
- **Priority**: 5 --> 1(low)
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: duly made additions to XSL. seems like a weird change to me, as it means vendors retooling for no advantage, when the notation isn't going to persist beyond acquisition anyway. but what the heck.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: Sebastian pointed out in a private email that I actually only renamed the element `cols` to `colShift` but didn't also change practice from using `@n` to `@cols` on this element. I find either attribute name equally transparent, and since I've just added bytes to the name of this element, I am reluctant to also add bytes on the attribute value.  So I'll leave it for now.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: I beg to disagree: the attribute @n should be used (like xml:id) to identify the shift itself, not to describe it. And since the shift being encoded here is not actually in the column (for which <cb/> already exists) but rather in the layout, I think a more appropriate name would be something like <layoutShift> or a contraction thereof if you really care about the bytes. But (as Sebastian says) is it really worth revising this now?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: - **status**: closed-fixed --> open
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text:
Lou makes a good point about TEI's semantics for `@n`.  However, the shift being encoded here is, in fact, in the columnar layout, so I think `<colShift>` is more transparent than `<layoutShift>`.  If we were going to have more than one type of layout shift, we might need `<layoutShift>`, but we're not to that point.

Both Sebastian and Lou asked whether it made sense to even rename the element when Tite is only meant as a transitory format.  It was easy to make the change, and I'd like for Tite elements to be named in a way that would allow them to be added to P5 as syntactic sugar someday in case people wanted them.  For that reason, `<colShift/>` is better than `<cols>`.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: Since Lou makes a good case for renaming @cols to @n, I have done so at https://sourceforge.net/p/tei/code/13094/ .  Added bonus: this new attribute has the datatype data.count, which will require a non-negative integer -- something that was intended anyway when riding on the global @n attribute.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed

posts.subject: #269 rename <cols/> to <colShift/>

tickets.description: Messages on TEI-L starting 28 Oct 2010 with subject "encoding musical drama" point to the need for some chunk-level element capable of combining multiple <sp> elements into a single unit without needing to open a <div>. A major use case is for passages of dialogue meant to be sung, perhaps with some assciated dialogue which are identified as distinct parts of a dramatic text, for example items labelled as "musical numbers" . Crucially, such items are at the same hierarchic level as the speeches which precede and follow them. The proposal is to define a new <spGrp> element which would stand in more or less the same relation to <sp> as does <lg> to <l> : it would be a member of model.divPart, and have a content model, and have the same content model as <sp>

tickets.description:
Introduce two new attributes for controlling the processing of XML examples within a TEI file. The two attributes should be in the TEI example namespace \(teix:\).

@teix:validates yes/no 
Semantics: if yes, the author of the example asserts the validity of the element with regards an implicitely \(corresponding namespace\) or explicitely \(by provision of the URI of a schema - how?\) defined schema. 
teix:validates="yes" is inherited until a teix:validates="no" is encountered
A processor may or may not check the validity again.
May be used to identify valid \(notoriously\) examples in an ODD spec.

teix: show yes/no
Semantics: the author of the example indicates that for whatever reason he does not wish that a subtree marked a teix:show="no" be shown in presentational output generated from the current example.
tei:show="yes" is inherited until a teix:show="no" is encountered

teix:show yes/no

posts.text: teix:show is skightly different from James' teix:noDisplay='true', since it applies to the nodes to be displayed or not and not to the parent of the nodes one does not want to display. This allows a better control on which subnodes one may want to show or not.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text: Any combination of the two attributes for a given example can be forseeen, of course.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
And sorry for the spam, I now see that James wanted the same as me, I quote:
It would, however, be better if the user could choose to see the 
missing bits or not in some cases, and the example was when fully 
shown a valid chunk of TEI.  So my suggesting is \*slightly\* 
different from what Sebastian suggests below.  Instead of putting 
the attribute  on the <fileDesc> I would have put it on the child 
elements since you may wish to hide some of them and not others. 
Moreover I would not have this be a binary true/false but 
instead have something like: 'collapsed', 'expanded', 'hidden',
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
I don't have any problem with  @show  \(though I would not give massive priority to implementing it\).

As regards @validates, I am not sure of the name. perhaps just @valid. But more importantly, I would differentiate three ways between 

1\. a tree which is fully valid against the chosen schema
2\. a tree which is feasibly valid against the chosen schema
3\. a tree which does not try to be valid at all \(<foo><bar/></foo>\)  

As regards having it as an attribute on the elements within the <egXML>, 
as opposed to on <egXML> itself, I am lukewarm. Supporting it on all
elements traversing down the tree is a lot more work \(and thats without
even implementing it\). 

Because I like a quiet life, I'd propose adding it to <egXML> and then
extending it later when/if the demand comes.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> rahtz
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
teix:show - I suppose that yes/no \(inherited as stated\) does what I want.... the reason I didn't make it boolean is for the possibility of distinguishing between things which we are hiding for pedagogical reasons \(we don't want to frighten you with this yet\) and things we \*never\* want to show.

teix:valid - I definitely feel that either the example as whole should be valid or it shouldn't be.  Having partly valid examples where we go through and say "This bit is valid, that bit is valid, oh, but this bit here isn't" seems overkill and a nightmare to implement. \(And for the use-case of the Guidelines, I don't think buys us much.\)  I also worry about the boolean datatype again, as SPQR notes it might be better to have 'valid', 'invalid', and 'feasibly' or something.

-j
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
- **labels**:  --> TEI: New or Changed Element
- **milestone**:  --> 871209
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
I like @valid, so long as Sebastian's suggestion of the value "feasible" is incorporated, as that seems the single most useful use of this in the guidelines: to be able to leave out unnecessarily complicated but strictly required elements from an example to which they're irrelevant. \(It occurs to me this might have bought us a chunk of what TEI Tite ended up leaving out too, mightn't it?\) And there must be examples of implementation against feasible validation out there.

@show I'm less convinced of the use-case for, now that the examples are solved \(\!\) with @valid...?
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
Gaby: My argument for @show \(or whatever\) remains the same.  I'd like to be able to present an example where some of the children/grandchildren were collapsed \(whether displayed as a comment or some expandable/collapsible bit of javascript depends on context\).  One of the benefits of this is it allows the presentation of quite a full example, but an initial display that is less threatening, and then as the user reads through information about the example, they can expand/collapse other parts of it.  Just making the decision on the processing-for-presentation side of things becomes immensely difficult without something in the source saying 'keep this one showing' and 'hide this one and its children', etc.  

This is, you are right, a completely separate issue from the validation of the examples \(just came up as a result of discussing possible ways to solve it\).

-James
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text: Further comment, if we agree that @show and @valid are different -- how is @show different from @rend ?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
two comments on Lou's proposed implementation
a\) add type="closed" to <valLlist>
b\) "yes", "no" and "feasibly" jar slightly as a group. Firstly,
we agreed to use "true" and "false" elsewhere, and secondly
the grammar seems odd.

true, false, and feasible

?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
Just to report, @valid is now present in the soon-to-be-released P5 1.9.0, with allowed values of true, false and feasible.

no agreement or progress on the other attribute
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
When we were examining this ticket at the Council F2F meeting, we felt a little confused by the wording of the description of the values for @valid as they currently appear in the guidelines. First of all, egXML is identified as containing an XML fragment. An XML fragment is a section of an XML document which is considered "well balanced":

"A region \(consecutive sequence of characters\) of an XML document is said to be \(well-\)balanced if it matches production \[43\] content of \[XML 1.0\]. Informally this means that, if the region includes any part of the markup of any construct, it contains all of the markup of that construct \(e.g., in the case of elements, all of both the start and end tag\)."

http://www.w3.org/TR/xml-fragment.html\#terminology

This implies that an XML fragment may consist of a pair or a group of siblings, not necessarily a single hierarchy rooted on one element. However, the subsequent definitions of @valid="true" and @valid="feasible" seem to require that a fragment in <egXML> be rooted on a single element, in order that it may be validated using a manipulated schema which is rooted on that element. If this is indeed the import of @valid, then the word "fragment", which in XML has a broader meaning than is intended here, should be removed from, or qualified in, the definition of <egXML>.

In addition to this, we believe two of the three value definitions could be clarified. Specifically>:

"true: 
the example is intended to be fully valid, assuming that its root element can be used as the root element in the schema concerned. \[Default\]"

The use of "can" here implies that a TEI schema can be rooted on any TEI element \(such as for example <p>\). This is not the case in a standard TEI schema, so the language should reflect that this is a hypothetical condition, by the use of "could" or "were able to" instead of "can".


"feasible:
the example could be transformed into a valid document by inserting any number of valid attributes and child elements anywhere within it; it is valid against a version of the schema concerned in which every data, list, element, or attribute element has been made optional."

Here our problems are with two phrases which we don't understand: "every data", and "attribute element". We suspect "attribute element" should simply read "attribute", but we don't actually know what is intended by "every data".
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
The apparently meaningless phrase is cut and pasted from the Jing specification at http://www.thaiopensource.com/relaxng/jing.html

"A document is feasibly valid if it could be transformed into a valid document by inserting any number of attributes and child elements anywhere in the tree. This is equivalent to transforming the schema by wrapping every data, list, element and attribute element in an optional element and then validating against the transformed schema." 

What cutting and pasting obscures is that the words  "data"," list", "element", "attribute" and "optional" are typographically distinct: they are actually element names in the RelaxNG schema being validated. One hesitates to improve on James Clark's language but maybe the following is less confusing:

"This is equivalent to validating the document against a version of its schema which has been transformed by wrapping every data, list, element and attribute element it contains in an optional element"
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #271 Managing egXML content (validation and presentation)

posts.text:
Proposal 1: correct prose as per last two comments
Proposal 2: use tei:rend inside <egXML> to control rendering of egXML content

tickets.description:
\[This is a simplified replacement for \#2987832.\]

When creating a <biblStruct>, we currently have to include <imprint> inside <monogr> in order to get <date>. This is rather silly in the case of such items as podcasts, blog entries, or electronic documents, which have no imprint at all. Also, both analytic- and monographic-level documents may have dates \(a blog post is presumably analytic, as part of a larger blog, but has its own date; a page on a website may have a publication date of its own, which does not apply to the website as a whole. <date> should be available as a child of <analytic> in order to allow for this.

The content model of <analytic> appears to list elements rather than using classes, so we could simply add <date> to the list.

posts.text: Happy to defer to a librarian on this, but I think the problem with this suggestion is that "analytic entry" \(which is what <analytic> is for\) is one of those concepts that really doesn't translate well into the digital world. My belief is that was originally invented as a way of providing "added entries" for titles/authors/ etc. of works otherwise unidentifiable within the work being catalogued. Extra access points that is. In a blog or digital file, however, the individual entries are already individully accessible: they are thus monographic rather than analytic. Where the analogy breaks down is that we can't then treat the whole blog itself as a monographic entry. Maybe that should be an analytic, or a series titles?  Apologies if this seems unduly pedantic, or has already been discussed to death. I note btw that you can already put <date> inside <title>
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #273 Add <date> as child of <analytic>

posts.text:
I don't know how relevant the history is to the problem we're facing right now. In current practice, <analytic> is used for journal articles and book chapters, with their host issues or books handled in the associated <monogr>, and the \(heretofore reasonable\) implication is that chapters and articles inherit their dates from their containing object. The guidelines themselves say "<analytic> \(analytic level\) contains bibliographic elements describing an item \(e.g. an article or poem\) published within a monograph or journal and not as an independent publication." Now we have contained objects which do \_not\_ inherit their date from the container \(blog posts, etc.\), so they need their own date. I'd say that blog posts are manifestly not standalone monographic objects; they're published all together in one location, in series, like a diary.

I think the argument is strong here, but if you disagree, then I think it's another nail in the coffin of <biblStruct> from my point of view. When you can't actually use <biblStruct> to encode what you believe in good faith to be "true" about real-life bibliographical items -- in this case, that contained objects may have a date which is independent of their container -- then the construct becomes simply tyrannical, and nobody is going to want to use it. I've already migrated my more recent projects to <bibl> instead because of these limitations.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #273 Add <date> as child of <analytic>

posts.text:
"Added entries" in cataloging covers any entry besides the main entry under which a catalog card would be filed.  So it covers many things, only a few of which would apply to a part of the whole item being cataloged.

It seems to me more precise to say that <analytic> was created for metadata about things for which, in most Anglo-American citation formats, the title is given within quotation marks \(inverted commas\).  On the other hand, <monogr> is used for metadata about things for which, in most citation formats, the title is given in italics.  Other conventions exist in other format \(like slashes and double slashes in ISBD-conformant formats\).

I believe most citation formats would treat give the title of a blog in italics and the title of a particular blog post in italics.  Therefore, we would encode the blog as a whole in <monogr> and the blog posting in <analytic>.

So I agree with Martin that we need <date> as a child of <analytic>
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #273 Add <date> as child of <analytic>

posts.text: Added date as another option in the content model at rev 8692
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #273 Add <date> as child of <analytic>

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
- **status**: open --> closed-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #273 Add <date> as child of <analytic>

I fell tempted to wonder whether we shouldn't start deprecating biblFull now, with a view to dropping it at P6 \(or sooner\) : it's sole raison d'etre, as a means of embedding one TEI header's file statement in another's\) has never really been taken up, and could maybe be met by other means.

To address the specific question here, though: I guess one good way forward might be to define a model class model.seriesNamePart \(calling it "model.seriesPart" would confuse far too many librarians\)

tickets.description:
The content model for <ident> currently permits text only, which makes
sense for most applications: one is unlikely to want to use a
non-Unicode character or a linebreak in the middle of an XML element
name or a filename. However, there are places where it is necessary to
split an identifier into constituent parts, which may even be
formatted differently. One obvious example are identifiers like
"\[filename\].xsl" or "tei-roma-\{version\}-\{hardware\}.deb" where the
\[filename\] , \{version\} etc are themselves identifiers, \(standing for a
filename, or a version number\) embedded within the identifier being
talked about, and which one might want to render in a different way
from the rest of the text, by italicising, wrapping in brackets
etc. To support this, I would propose that <ident> should have a
content model of text|ident\* It would then be possible to say
e.g.<p>The current release is available in the file
<ident>tei-roma-<ident rend="italics">version</ident>.deb</ident>,
where <ident rend="italics">version</ident> is the current version
number</p> The small downside of this is that XML syntax requires us
to accept a null string or element content only as a valid identifier,
so we might need to add a schematron rule to say that an ident must
have at least one text child.

posts.text:
I am not keen on this at all, for various reasons

a\) moving <ident> from being a simple object to a complex one will mean anyone who implements stylesheets for TEI  may fall over. currently you can rely on <ident> containing text, parallel to @ident, and may \(for example\) use it in non-typeset contexts \(in generated data, as a link etc\).

b\) the example does not hold up:

tei-roma-\{version\}-\{hardware\}.deb

is a \_not\_ a real identifier, its a pseudo-identifier. none of tei-roma-, version or hardware are identifiers. Put the whole thing in <hi rend="ident">, with embedded <hi> if needed, and your problem is solved.

c\) if you want decorated identifiers, then just nested <ident> is insufficient. how will you expressa graphical component of a pseudo-identifie
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text:
Clearly, we  don't agree on the semantics of <ident>, You apparently want to restrict it to mean the same thing as @ident; I want to use it more generally for any form of identifier such as a filename, or what you call  a "pseudo-identifier" below, tho what is "pseudo" about the kind of use I suggest I don't know. But even leaving aside that "pseudo" usage for an identifier which has to be dereferenced before you can use it, surely you'd agree that an identifier can be built up hierarchically of other identifiers? What about a URL, for example: would <ident><ident type="base">www.tei-c.org</ident><ident>index.xml</ident></ident> be so very evil? Or what about a filename like <ident><ident>foo/</ident><ident>bar.txt</ident></ident>

I don't want "decorated identifiers", whatever they might be:  as ever, the formatting is the effect, not the cause of the required distinction If you won't let me do it with <ident>, I suppose I could do it with <name> or <rs>.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text: - **milestone**: 871208 --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text: Additional proposal would allow <idno> to self-nest, but this doesnt meet use case for "pseudo-identifiers" like "\[filename\].xml" for which we propose using rs or name. Need to clarify somewhere when to use <idno> and when to use <ident>.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> martindholmes
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text:
There has been substantial discussion of this on the TEI Council list, following this decision of Council in Paris:

\[minutes\]
3188679: Change content model of <ident> . MH, LR: LB's use-case is actually a use-case for <idno> , not for <ident> . For instance, he uses URLs and filenames, and both of these should be <idno> . However, <idno> also does not permit internal structure, and there are other use-cases where that would be a good idea \(for instance ISBNs and ISSNs\). At the same time, <ident> does have a specific purpose, which is tagging formal identifiers in e.g. programming languages, and these do not typically have internal structure. Finally, we are sympathetic to Sebastian's objections related to processing. Therefore we propose that <idno> should be made recursive, allowing internal structure, examples of recursive <idno> should be supplied, and LB should be encouraged to use <idno> instead of <ident> for his purposes. EP strongly objected that the subdivisions of <idno> are not necessarily <idno>s. LB says that the difference between <ident> and <idno> definitely needs some clarification. Assigned to MH to clarify the guidelines on the difference between <idno> and <ident>, and close the ticket, and to LR to raise a new ticket for the nesting of <idno> so the council can address it at length. 
\[/minutes\]

After discussion, though, we seem to be a long way from a consensus, in that most people haven't expressed a view, and those of us that have seem to fall into two main camps: those who believe that <ident> and <idno> overlap substantially, and those who would like them not to, and want to word the guidelines accordingly.

However, nobody has actually objected to the wording that I proposed adding to the existing element definitions:

\----------
<ident> should be used for tokens such as variable names, class names, 
type names, function names etc. in formal programming languages. \(It 
should not be used for element and attribute names in XML, for which the special elements <gi> and <att> are provided.\)

<idno> should be used for labels which uniquely identify an object or 
concept in a formal cataloguing system such as a database or an RDF 
store, or in a distributed system such as the World Wide Web.
\----------

So unless someone does voice a spirited objection in the next little while, I propose adding those to the two <elementSpec>s. That pushes us oh-so-gently in the direction of making more of a distinction between the use-cases for the two elements. I'm then going to look at the text of these two sections:

<http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html\#COBICOI>

<http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/TD.html\#TDphrase>

to see if further disambiguation is possible or desirable in the text.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text: I'm closing this ticket, after making some minor adjustments to ident.xml and idno.xml in rev 9855.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #275 change content model of <ident>

tickets.description:
gramGrp serves to encode grammatical information about a lexical item. It may self-nest, thus providing containers for various feature groups.

By its nature, gramGrp appears to be a near-equivalent of a feature structure \(<fs>\). If it were to be fully equivalent to <fs>, it should get the additional "attribute type \{ data.enumerated \}?", because feature structures can be typed. However, full equivalence to an <fs> would also mean equivalent nesting, but that may not be realistic in dictionary entries, and therefore it seems appropriate to give the encoder both @type and @subtype at his disposal, so that these two attributes may be used to express both the type of a feature structure and, in a shorthand way, the information that would normally be read from the hierarchy of a feature structure tree.

Saying this, I have in mind HPSG-like robust feature structures, where containers identified as <fs type="agr"> may express, among others, 
a\) the agreement features that are property of the lexical item being described -- at one, shallow, level of nesting, and, \*at the same time\*
b\) the agreement features of an element that is, e.g., the obligatory complement of the lexical item in question, and thus the <fs type="agr"> is buried deep in the feature structure hierarchy.

\[I tried to find an example readable as HTML, but failed. Instead, these slides can give an idea of what I'm talking about:
http://jones.ling.indiana.edu/~mdickinson/08/614/slides/hpsg-slides.pdf
see slide 11 for a simple example of types repeated in a nesting structure, and slide 63 for something more extreme; I'm not sure I can attach them \(there's no licensing info there\) but I'll keep a copy in case they vanish from the Net\]

For the purpose of a dictionary/lexical database, full isomorphy between "true" feature structures and gramGrp would be absolute overkill \(compare the slides\), and in the case at hand could be replaced with, e.g., <gramGrp type="agr" subtype="head"> followed by <gramGrp type="agr" subtype="complement">.

There are various types of gramGrp that can be thought of, depending on the grammatical model and the lexicographic principles assumed. Therefore, I'd rather not enumerate the possible values of these attributes, delegating the task of creating such a mini-ontology to the encoder.

posts.text:
Let me also take this one level down, to actual lexicographic practice. The first time I saw the need for typing gramGrp was when preparing a dictionary of Swahili, where in some cases you have to distinguish between the morphological aspect of noun class \(if it bears the morphology -- and typically corresponds to the default semantic type -- of class C, then the plural should be formed in class D\) and its syntactic aspect \(normally, class C triggers "C-agreement" in verbs and adjectives, but if a C-class noun happens to be animate, it triggers "A-agreement", although the plural is formed in class D still\). So we need to refer to two types of class features at the same time, to handle the morphological aspect \(plural formation\) and the morphosyntactic aspect \(agreement\). This is why dictionaries of Swahili may seem messy to an outsider, because they either focus on one or on the other. \(And the picture gets even more complicated when we include agreement with possessive pronouns in it.\)

This isn't exclusive to Swahili. Another quick simplified example from Polish that I can think of is where some feminine nouns \(e.g. mość 'highness'\) trigger "grammatical" feminine agreement but sometimes also semantic masculine agreement \(if they denote males\), the result being:

his\(masc\) royal\(fem.\) highness\(fem./masc\) looked-around\(masc.\)

And my point is, to repeat: being able to type <gramGrp> would be a relief in such cases, because you definitely want to keep the two <gen> specifications in separate <gramGrp>s, and then you want to know which <gramGrp> pertains to which aspects of the realisation of the word in question.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #276 att.typed for gramGrp

posts.text:
I think <gramGrp> is \*very\* different from <fs>: it serves simply as a means of grouping together a number of other elements related to \(loosely defined\) grammatical information for a lexical entry. You could do something similar  with a <fs>, but <gramGrp> is much more specific, and should be left that way -- if you want the level of complexity offered by <fs>, use <fs>, don't complexify existing things unnecessarily.

However, if all you mean is that it would be useful to add @type and @subtype to <gramGrp> to distinguish different kinds of such groupings in some way, I  see no reason to object to the proposal.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #276 att.typed for gramGrp

- **status**: open --> open-accepted

tickets.description: While transforming EEBO-TCP texts into P5, I have come across many instances where the P5 model for postscript is inadequate. <postscript> does not permit opening and closing elements. But it is not uncommon for a postscript to be a microversion of the letter to which it is appended, with some form of "Dear Sir" and some form of "Sincerely yours, John Smith."  Opener and closer elements would be welcome. Right now you would either have to downshift the encoding to <ab> or turn a more complex postscript into floatingText. Neither of these is an attractive solution.

posts.text:
FWIW, the TCP element that Martin refers to \(a local customization which actually predates the P5 element of the same name\) has a content model that closely
matches that of a div7 -- that is, it is basically a div \(with divtop and divbottom elements
allowed\), but is restricted by not allowing subdivving, and is further restricted by
virtue of being allowed only within closer. Its content model, expressed in dtd-talk, is as follows. It is small, of course, because our scheme is in general very much stripped down \(or impoverished, if you like\).


<\!ELEMENT postscript \(\(head | opener | lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*,
\(\(p | l | lg | q | list | letter | license | floatext | note | stage | sp | bibl\), 
\(lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*\)+,
\(\(closer | tailnote | trailer\), \(lb | milestone | pb | gap\)\*\)\*\)  >

\('tailnote' and 'floatext' are other customizations, of self-evident meaning.\)

pfs
posts.author: pfschaffner
posts.subject: #279 modify postscript

posts.text: When <postscript> was introduced, it was agreed to reserve it for simple postscriupts only, and to represent other more complex structures either with <ab> or with <div>. It is hard to see why a  "postscript" should get its own special tag and a "chapter" not -- they are both divs.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #279 modify postscript

posts.text:
I see the force of this argument, but it's an even stronger argument for not having postscript in the first place. "postscript" is a part of "letter", and if there is no letter tag why should there be a postscript. So there would be a logic to using <ab> for simple cases and <div> for more complex cases. In the EEBO collection there are things called postscript that are whole treatises, and whatever is the right way of encoding them, <postscript> is not it. 

On the other hand, once you have <postscript>, it's hard not to notice that even short ones are full of openers and closers, salutations, and signatures. So it seems to me that the current content rules for postscript are stuck in an uncomfortable middle, and it might be better either to move back or forward. 

But thinking about this raises broader problems. If you think of elements in very broad terms you might want to get rid of all genre-specific elements. Drama is a relatively privileged genre in TEI \(the division of prose, verse, and drama may be an odd reflection of the trinity of epic, drama, and lyric, with its own very genre specific tags. We run into the same inconsistencies. There are no elements for act or scene, but there are elements for prologue and epilogue, and for "speech", although one could made a good case that "said" would do just fine.

It's tough, and I could see going either way, although I'd probably rather go on a "less is more" path, which might mean abandoning rather than expanding postscript and other elements that sit at a similar level of genre specificity,

On the other hand, convenience is convenience. If we have <lb> for <milestone unit="line"\)
, why not admit the typographical elements of TEI Tite, which let you write y<sup>e</sup> rather than y<hi rend="superscript>e</hi>.

A lot of ambiguity here that cannot be solved and has to be lived with.
posts.author: martinmueller
posts.subject: #279 modify postscript

posts.text: Agreed to change content model to \(model.divTop|model.global\)\* , model.common\*  , \(\(model.divBottom|model.global\)
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #279 modify postscript

posts.text:
- **milestone**: 871209 --> GREEN

- **status**: open --> pending
posts.author: louburnard

posts.text: duly implemented

tickets.description:
1\. The element <colloc> is defined as containing a "collocate", but this term isn't defined in the Guidelines or in widely available dictionaries.

2\. <colloc type="prep"> is unclear: does this mean that the value of <colloc> goes before what's in <orth> or that what goes in <orth> goes before this collocate?  According to people who know French better than me, the example is supposed to mean the latter, but I would not have guessed that by reading of the markup.  This example needs a bit of glossing.

3\. Perhaps we should add to the element definition recommended values for @type, explaining that "prep" means that what's in <orth> goes before this collocate.

posts.text: I agree that the explanation of uses for this element is somewhat deficient, not so say gnomic. I am also puzzled by how to interpret the @type=prep example, which I read quite differently from you: as indicating the "medire" is to be followed by the preposition "de", rather than say the preposition "a". Clearly we need an expert to tell us which is right, so I am assigning this ticket to Laurent\!
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> 871209
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> romary
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: yep, "prep" stands for preposition; "collocate" is a common term in corpus linguistics and lexicography, even if dictionaries don't list it :-\)
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: But let me add that putting "prep" here like this is a bit strange for someone who is responsible for ISO DCR, Laurent... ;-\)
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
- **milestone**: 871209 --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> pending-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
At the Paris meeting in November 2011 we accepted this ticket and assigned to Laurent.  Given how much time has elapsed, I would implement it myself, but I'm still not clear how to do so.

I would like to see a brief gloss of "collocate" for those who don't work in corpus linguisics, and I would like to see (2) and (3) resolved.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: I must this has escaped my radar and should deserve a little thinking before we go any further. First, we need to make sure we agree on the actual notion we want to express. Would "any word of sequence of words that significantly occur on conjunction with the head word" do the trick? We also need to see whether we actually want to say something about @type: "preposition", "support verb", "argument", "qualia" ? Quite a few possibilities there which we should want to leave open. The last issue may be to indicate frequency information... but this should come after the TEI conf. I think a contribution about this has been submitted.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
For (1) in the original ticket, as a definition of collocate, your phrase sounds to me like a collocation, though I think of a collocation as not having any relation to a particular headword.

Anyway, I would reword your definition of collocate as "any sequence of words that co-occur with the headword with significant frequency".

For (2) and (3), I don't know enough about collocates to agree or disagree with Laurent's options.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Your rewording is fine!
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
Okay, (1) is now solved at revision 11848.

Still need to solve (2) and (3).
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
Looking at this for the first time, it strikes me that the `<colloc>` element doesn't seem to provide any way to encode how the collocation is formed -- for instance words, does the word in the `<colloc>` element come before or after the headword? 

Wouldn't some kind of `<phr>`-based structure be better for showing the headword in the context of a collocation?
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Example @types would be fine, but (as on many other occasions) I would suggest **not to recommend** any specific values, because at that point, the Guidelines would go beyond their aim, and fail. They aren't meant to be guidelines for dictionary writing, are they.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Martin, the ordering could be indicated by @type more or less directly, e.g. "object" or "_ of NP", etc. -- I suggest to leave that to the particular system (which every serious dictionary is).
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: That's right: while it's not explained in the element definition for <colloc> (perhaps an oversight that we should fix), in section 9.3.2 (#DITPGR) it gives an example using @type.  Confusion over how to interpret this led to questions (2) and (3) in this ticket.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: Laurent Romary --> Kevin Hawkins
- **Priority**: 5 --> 1(low)
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Per discussion at Council meeting, we agreed to remove @type on `<colloc>` from the example in section 9.3.2 and in the spec for `<colloc>` because it's misleading.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Will `<colloc>` be in att.typed, though? Or are you breaking backwards compatibility?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: We didn't discuss explicitly, but I wasn't planning to change its class.  Therefore people would be free to continue using @type on their own if they like, whether they used it to indicate a type of collocate, the part of speech of the content of the element, or something else.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

posts.text: Great, thanks. It would be bad to see @type go altogether.

posts.subject: #280 clarification of <colloc>

tickets.description:
http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-att.global.html says, "If no value is specified for xml:lang, the xml:lang value for the immediately enclosing element is inherited; for this reason, a value should always be specified on the outermost element \(TEI\)."

I dislike this because it assumes that the primary language of the content of of the header are the same.  While this is often the case, there are entire collections where this is not the case, and many collections involve a mix of documents in which this is only sometimes the case.

I think it would promote clearer thinking and more straightforward interoperability if this were revised to say: "If no value is specified for xml:lang, the xml:lang value for the immediately enclosing element is inherited; for this reason, a value should always be specified on both teiHeader for the primary language of the metadata and on text \(or fsDecl or facsimile\) for the primary language of the content."

posts.text:
The proposed change seems quite plausible, though I think I would phrase it more loosely, since the revision doesnt really help in cases where you have say a <group> of texts using different languages. 

How about "... the xml:lang value will be inherited from the immediately enclosing element, or from its parent, and so on up the document hierarchy. It is generally good practice to specify xml:lang at the highest appropriate level, noticing that a different default may be needed  for the teiHeader from that needed for the associated resource element or elements, and that a single TEI document may contain texts in many languages."
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text:
- **labels**: 666891 --> TEI: Guidelines Documentation Suggestion
- **milestone**:  --> 871208
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text:
I had forgotten about <group>.  While I am at first inclined to simply change my proposed text to say

and on text \(or group, fsDecl, or facsimile\)

I can live with Lou's proposed text.  It's simpler and easier to maintain in the long run \(in case we implement the pending genetic editions thing\).  Unfortunately, it means that people processing TEI documents from various sources will need to look at TEI@xml:lang in case <text>, <group>, <fsDecl>, or <facsimile> is missing an @xml:lang.  That is, I was trying to promote clearer thinking about the difference between metadata and content and to facilitate straightforward processing.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text: I prefer Lou's wording, in part because many documents \(perhaps even the majority\) will still be fine with @xml:lang on the TEI element. I don't think enumerating approprite high-level elements will help much, since sometimes languages change at the level of divs, or differ between front and body, for example.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text: I agree with Lou's wording, it makes it looser, I didn't like the "should always".
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text: Added new wording at rev 9636
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

posts.subject: #281 inheritance of @xml:lang

tickets.summary: allow underscores in math to be used for subscripts
tickets.description:
This concerns only the LaTeX stylesheets.

From what I understand support for math goes beyond what the stylesheets are designed to provide. This is understandable. However, as currently designed, the stylesheets create one obstacle to simple support for mathematics encoded according to TeX notation. I have a stylesheet which imports the latex2.xsl stylesheet but also has the necessary overrides so that this should work:

<formula notation="TeX">x\_1</formula>

It should produce a "x" symbol with a subscripted 1. However, because the catcode for underscore is redefined by the stylesheet bundled with the TEI files, it generates "x" followed by an underscore followed by 1. In other words, the way the stylesheet currently works, underscore means underscore everywhere. Searching for solutions I came across the following code fragment:

\begingroup
\catcode\`\\\_=\active
\gdef\_\#1\{\ensuremath\{\sb\{\mathrm\{\#1\}\}\}\}
\endgroup
\mathcode\`\\\_=\string"8000
\catcode\`\\\_=12

I must admit this is beyond what I normally have to fiddle with when I use LaTeX but from what I understand, this ensures that underscore is treated as underscore outside of math but when in math it performs its traditional subscript function.

I have used the above code fragment without problem so far.

posts.text: interesting. the trick does indeed seem to work. duly added, thanks
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #283 allow underscores in math to be used for subscripts

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-accepted
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #283 allow underscores in math to be used for subscripts

tickets.description:
Both the W3C \(who define XML\) and the IETF \(who define URIs\) call sequences of characters accessible via a URI 'documents.' In many places throughout the standard we call them 'files' We should regularise on 'documents' for clarity and to avoid confusion.

We should leave the word 'file' when it is part of a larger term \('authority file'\).

Changing the name of 'fileDesc' shouldn't be done until a suitable major revision.

posts.text: I don't like 'file' myself. So agree.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text:
To restate this: the IETF calls URI-identifiable things resources \(see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986 \) and the w3c calls resources which are valid XML 'documents' \(see http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-xml-20081126/ \); we should follow this terminology. The standard should talk about TEI/XML being in 'documents' not 'files' and URIs/URLs attributes should point to 'resources'.

The TEI tag fileDesc should be changed in the fullness of time to 'docDesc,' in the internum a note should be added to it's description as to why it is named as it is.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: Happy to embark on a hunt for "file"s which should be "document"s, but please note that "fileDesc" is unlikely to change as long as we want to stick with the ISBD.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: Maybe fileDesc gets a note about that naming decision, complete with a reference to http://archive.ifla.org/VII/s13/pubs/isbd2.htm ?
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: I agree that we need to be consistent, but we have to be careful about blanket changes; not all files are documents, and not all documents are files, so there will most likely be contexts in which we really mean "file", even when referring to something containing XML.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text:
Lou, when you say "fileDesc is unlikely to change as long as we want to
stick with the ISBD", do you mean that ISBD uses the term "file" as a material type for an electronic document?  First of all, the ISBD doesn't do that, though some ISBD-derived standards may do so.  But even if they do, we would still keep the same child elements of <fileDesc>, which roughly correspond to the various components of an ISBD description, so I don't see any harm here.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: While I acknowledge that TEI has been influenced by ISBD, it seems to me that, all other things being equal we should favour W3C / IETF terminology, because these standards bodies are currently in ascendancy, more people are familiar with their terminology.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: The ticket is about hunting 'file' in the documentation and not about changing fileDesc. Let us agree that we try to use document in a consistent way in the guidelines.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: in some theoretical world, I agree with Stuart that we should use document in place of file. But I also thinking this work is very low priority indeed, and is going to be tedious, delicate work. Who is volunteering to do is?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: Agreed that this is probably not worth sustained work for the moment.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #285 replace 'file' with 'document'

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
